**Athens^[\[a\]](#cite_note-6)^** ([/ˈæθɪnz/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*ATH-inz*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"))^[\[6\]](#cite_note-7)^ is the capital and [largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Greece "List of cities and towns in Greece") of [Greece](/wiki/Greece "Greece"). A major coastal urban area in the Mediterranean, Athens is also the capital of the [Attica region](/wiki/Attica_(region) "Attica (region)") and is the southernmost capital on the [European mainland](/wiki/European_mainland "European mainland"). With its urban area's population numbering over 3.6 million, it is the [eighth largest urban area](/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_the_European_Union "List of urban areas in the European Union") in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union"). The [Municipality of Athens](/wiki/Municipality_of_Athens "Municipality of Athens") (also City of Athens), which constitutes a small administrative unit of the entire urban area, had a population of 643,452 (2021)^[\[4\]](#cite_note-census21-4)^ within its official limits, and a land area of 38.96 km^2^ (15.04 sq mi).^[\[7\]](#cite_note-stat01-8)^^[\[8\]](#cite_note-area-9)^{#cite_ref-area_9-0}

Athens is one of the [world's oldest cities](/wiki/List_of_oldest_continuously_inhabited_cities "List of oldest continuously inhabited cities"), with its [recorded history](/wiki/Recorded_history "Recorded history") spanning over 3,400 years,^[\[9\]](#cite_note-10)^ and its earliest human presence beginning somewhere between the 11th and 7th millennia [BC](/wiki/Anno_Domini "Anno Domini"). According to Greek mythology the city was named after [Athena](/wiki/Athena "Athena"), the ancient Greek goddess of wisdom, but modern scholars generally agree that the goddess took her name after the city.^[\[10\]](#cite_note-11)^ [Classical Athens](/wiki/Classical_Athens "Classical Athens") was one of the most powerful [city-states](/wiki/Polis "Polis") in [ancient Greece](/wiki/Ancient_Greece "Ancient Greece"). It was a centre for democracy, the arts, education and philosophy,^[\[11\]](#cite_note-12)^^[\[12\]](#cite_note-13)^ and was highly influential throughout the European continent, particularly in [Ancient Rome](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome").^[\[13\]](#cite_note-14)^ For this reason, it is often regarded as the [cradle](/wiki/Cradle_of_civilization "Cradle of civilization") of [Western civilization](/wiki/Western_civilization "Western civilization") and the [birthplace of democracy](/wiki/History_of_democracy "History of democracy") in its own right independently from the rest of Greece.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-britannica-15)^^[\[15\]](#cite_note-bbc-16)^{#cite_ref-bbc_16-0}

In modern times, Athens is a large cosmopolitan [metropolis](/wiki/Metropolis "Metropolis") and central to economic, financial, industrial, maritime, political and cultural life in Greece. It is a [Beta (+)](/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network#Beta "Globalization and World Cities Research Network") -- status [global city](/wiki/Global_city "Global city") according to the [Globalization and World Cities Research Network](/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network "Globalization and World Cities Research Network"),^[\[16\]](#cite_note-17)^ and is one of the biggest economic centers in Southeastern Europe. It also has a large financial sector, and its port [Piraeus](/wiki/Piraeus "Piraeus") is both the 2nd busiest passenger port in Europe,^[\[17\]](#cite_note-ESPO-18)^ and the 13th largest container port in the world.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-19)^ The [Athens metropolitan area](/wiki/Athens_metropolitan_area "Athens metropolitan area")^[\[19\]](#cite_note-20)^ extends beyond its administrative municipal city limits as well as its [urban agglomeration](/wiki/Urban_Agglomeration "Urban Agglomeration"), with a population of 3,638,281 (2021)^[\[4\]](#cite_note-census21-4)^^[\[20\]](#cite_note-21)^^[\[21\]](#cite_note-22)^ over an area of 2,928.717 km^2^ (1,131 sq mi).^[\[8\]](#cite_note-area-9)^{#cite_ref-area_9-1}

The heritage of the [Classical Era](/wiki/Classical_Greece "Classical Greece") is still evident in the city, represented by [ancient monuments](/wiki/Ancient_monument "Ancient monument"), and works of art, the most famous of all being the [Parthenon](/wiki/Parthenon "Parthenon"), considered a key landmark of early [Western culture](/wiki/Western_culture "Western culture"). The city also retains [Roman](/wiki/Roman_Greece "Roman Greece"), [Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire") and a smaller number of [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") monuments, while its historical urban core features elements of continuity through its millennia of history. Athens is home to two [UNESCO World Heritage Sites](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites "UNESCO World Heritage Sites"), the [Acropolis of Athens](/wiki/Acropolis_of_Athens "Acropolis of Athens") and the medieval [Daphni Monastery](/wiki/Daphni_Monastery "Daphni Monastery"). Athens is also home to several museums and cultural institutions, such as the [National Archeological Museum](/wiki/National_Archaeological_Museum,_Athens "National Archaeological Museum, Athens"), featuring the world's largest collection of ancient Greek antiquities, the [Acropolis Museum](/wiki/Acropolis_Museum "Acropolis Museum"), the [Museum of Cycladic Art](/wiki/Goulandris_Museum_of_Cycladic_Art "Goulandris Museum of Cycladic Art"), the [Benaki Museum](/wiki/Benaki_Museum "Benaki Museum"), and the [Byzantine and Christian Museum](/wiki/Byzantine_and_Christian_Museum "Byzantine and Christian Museum"). Athens was the host city of the [first modern-day Olympic Games](/wiki/1896_Summer_Olympics "1896 Summer Olympics") in 1896, and 108 years later it hosted the [2004 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics "2004 Summer Olympics"), making it one of five cities to have hosted the Summer Olympics on multiple occasions.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-oly-23)^{#cite_ref-oly_23-0}  

Etymology and names {#Etymology_and_names}
------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Etymology and names")\]  
Further information: [Names of European cities in different languages (A)](/wiki/Names_of_European_cities_in_different_languages_(A) "Names of European cities in different languages (A)")

In [Ancient Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greek_language "Ancient Greek language"), the name of the city was Ἀθῆναι (*Athênai* ,
pronounced [\[atʰɛ̂ːnai̯\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Greek "Help:IPA/Greek") in [Classical Attic](/wiki/Attic_Greek "Attic Greek")), which is a plural word. In earlier Greek, such as [Homeric Greek](/wiki/Homeric_Greek "Homeric Greek"), the name had been current in the singular form though, as Ἀθήνη (*Athḗnē* ).^[\[23\]](#cite_note-24)^ It was possibly rendered in the plural later on, like those of Θῆβαι (*[Thêbai](/wiki/Thebes,_Greece "Thebes, Greece")* ) and Μυκῆναι (*[Μukênai](/wiki/Mycenae "Mycenae")* ). The root of the word is probably not of Greek or [Indo-European](/wiki/Indo-European_languages "Indo-European languages") origin,^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Beekes2009-25)^ and is possibly a remnant of the [Pre-Greek substrate](/wiki/Pre-Greek_substrate "Pre-Greek substrate") of Attica.^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Beekes2009-25)^ In antiquity, it was debated whether Athens took its name from its patron goddess [Athena](/wiki/Athena "Athena") ([Attic](/wiki/Attic_Greek "Attic Greek") Ἀθηνᾶ, *Athēnâ* , [Ionic](/wiki/Ionic_Greek "Ionic Greek") Ἀθήνη, *Athḗnē* , and [Doric](/wiki/Doric_Greek "Doric Greek") Ἀθάνα, *Athā́nā* ) or Athena took her name from the city.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-Burkert1985-26)^ Modern scholars now generally agree that the goddess takes her name from the city,^[\[25\]](#cite_note-Burkert1985-26)^ because the ending -*ene* is common in names of locations, but rare for personal names.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-Burkert1985-26)^{#cite_ref-Burkert1985_26-2}

According to the ancient Athenian [founding myth](/wiki/Founding_myth "Founding myth"), Athena, the goddess of wisdom and war, competed against [Poseidon](/wiki/Poseidon "Poseidon"), the God of the Seas, for patronage of the yet-unnamed city;^[\[26\]](#cite_note-Kerényi1951-27)^ they agreed that whoever gave the Athenians the better gift would become their patron^[\[26\]](#cite_note-Kerényi1951-27)^ and appointed [Cecrops](/wiki/Cecrops_I "Cecrops I"), the king of Athens, as the judge.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-Kerényi1951-27)^ According to the account given by [Pseudo-Apollodorus](/wiki/Bibliotheca_(Pseudo-Apollodorus) "Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)"), Poseidon struck the ground with his [trident](/wiki/Trident_of_Poseidon "Trident of Poseidon") and a salt water spring welled up.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-Kerényi1951-27)^ In an alternative version of the myth from [Vergil](/wiki/Vergil "Vergil")'s poem *[Georgics](/wiki/Georgics "Georgics")* , Poseidon instead gave the Athenians the first horse.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-Kerényi1951-27)^ In both versions, Athena offered the Athenians the first domesticated [olive tree](/wiki/Olive_tree "Olive tree").^[\[26\]](#cite_note-Kerényi1951-27)^^[\[27\]](#cite_note-Garland2008-28)^ Cecrops accepted this gift^[\[26\]](#cite_note-Kerényi1951-27)^ and declared Athena the patron goddess of Athens.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-Kerényi1951-27)^^[\[27\]](#cite_note-Garland2008-28)^ Eight different etymologies, now commonly rejected, have been proposed since the 17th century. [Christian Lobeck](/wiki/Christian_Lobeck "Christian Lobeck") proposed as the root of the name the word ἄθος (*áthos* ) or ἄνθος (*ánthos* ) meaning "flower", to denote Athens as the "flowering city". [Ludwig von Döderlein](/wiki/Johann_Christoph_Wilhelm_Ludwig_D%C3%B6derlein "Johann Christoph Wilhelm Ludwig Döderlein") proposed the stem of the verb θάω, stem θη- (*tháō* , *thē-* , "to suck") to denote Athens as having fertile soil.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-29)^ Athenians were called [cicada](/wiki/Cicada "Cicada")-wearers (Ancient Greek: Τεττιγοφόροι) because they used to wear pins of golden cicadas. A symbol of being [autochthonous](/wiki/Autochthon_(ancient_Greece) "Autochthon (ancient Greece)") (earth-born), because the legendary founder of Athens, [Erechtheus](/wiki/Erechtheus "Erechtheus") was an autochthon or of being musicians, because the cicada is a "musician" insect.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-30)^ In classical literature, the city was sometimes referred to as the [City of the Violet Crown](/wiki/City_of_the_Violet_Crown "City of the Violet Crown"), first documented in Pindar's ἰοστέφανοι Ἀθᾶναι (*iostéphanoi Athânai* ), or as τὸ κλεινὸν ἄστυ (*tò kleinòn ásty*, "the glorious city").{#cite_ref-30}

During the medieval period, the name of the city was rendered once again in the singular as Ἀθήνα. Variant names included Setines, Satine, and Astines, all derivations involving [false splitting](/wiki/False_splitting "False splitting") of prepositional phrases.^[\[30\]](#cite_note-Bourne1887-31)^ King [Alphonse X of Castile](/wiki/Alfonso_X_of_Castile "Alfonso X of Castile") gives the pseudo-etymology 'the one without death/ignorance'.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-32)^^\[*[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")*\]^ In Ottoman Turkish, it was called
آتينا‎ *Ātīnā* ,^[\[32\]](#cite_note-33)^ and in modern Turkish, it is *Atina*.{#cite_ref-33}

### Antiquity {#Antiquity}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Antiquity")\]  
Main articles: [Classical Athens](/wiki/Classical_Athens "Classical Athens"), [Hellenistic Greece](/wiki/Hellenistic_Greece "Hellenistic Greece"), and [Roman Greece](/wiki/Roman_Greece "Roman Greece")

The oldest known human presence in Athens is the Cave of Schist, which has been dated to between the 11th and 7th millennia BC.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ethnos.gr-34)^ Athens has been continuously inhabited for at least 5,000 years (3000 BC).^[\[34\]](#cite_note-35)^^[\[35\]](#cite_note-tung-36)^ By 1400 BC, the settlement had become an important centre of the [Mycenaean](/wiki/Mycenaean_Greece "Mycenaean Greece") civilization, and the [Acropolis](/wiki/Acropolis_of_Athens "Acropolis of Athens") was the site of a major [Mycenaean](/wiki/Mycenae "Mycenae") fortress, whose remains can be recognised from sections of the characteristic [Cyclopean](/wiki/Cyclopean "Cyclopean") walls.^[\[36\]](#cite_note-37)^ Unlike other Mycenaean centers, such as [Mycenae](/wiki/Mycenae "Mycenae") and [Pylos](/wiki/Pylos "Pylos"), it is not known whether Athens suffered destruction in about 1200 BC, an event often attributed to a [Dorian](/wiki/Dorians "Dorians") invasion, and the Athenians always maintained that they were pure [Ionians](/wiki/Ionians "Ionians") with no Dorian element. However, Athens, [like many other Bronze Age settlements](/wiki/Bronze_Age_collapse "Bronze Age collapse"), went into economic decline for around 150 years afterwards.^[\[37\]](#cite_note-38)^ [Iron Age](/wiki/Iron_Age "Iron Age") burials, in the [Kerameikos](/wiki/Kerameikos "Kerameikos")^[\[38\]](#cite_note-39)^ and other locations, are often richly provided for and demonstrate that from 900 BC onwards Athens was one of the leading centres of trade and prosperity in the region.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-40)^{#cite_ref-40}

By the sixth century BC, widespread social unrest led to the reforms of [Solon](/wiki/Solon "Solon"). These would pave the way for the eventual introduction of democracy by [Cleisthenes](/wiki/Cleisthenes "Cleisthenes") in 508 BC. Athens had by this time become a significant naval power with a large fleet, and helped the [rebellion of the Ionian cities](/wiki/Ionian_Revolt "Ionian Revolt") against [Persian](/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire "Achaemenid Empire") rule. In the ensuing [Greco-Persian Wars](/wiki/Greco-Persian_Wars "Greco-Persian Wars") Athens, together with Sparta, led the coalition of Greek states that would eventually repel the Persians, defeating them decisively at [Marathon](/wiki/Battle_of_Marathon "Battle of Marathon") in 490 BC, and crucially at [Salamis](/wiki/Battle_of_Salamis "Battle of Salamis") in 480 BC. However, this did not prevent Athens from being [captured and sacked twice](/wiki/Achaemenid_destruction_of_Athens "Achaemenid destruction of Athens") by the Persians within one year, after a heroic but ultimately failed resistance at [Thermopylae](/wiki/Battle_of_Thermopylae "Battle of Thermopylae") by [Spartans](/wiki/Sparta "Sparta") and other Greeks led by [King Leonidas](/wiki/Leonidas_I "Leonidas I"),^[\[40\]](#cite_note-41)^ after both [Boeotia](/wiki/Boeotia "Boeotia") and [Attica](/wiki/Attica "Attica") fell to the Persians.{#cite_ref-41}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Map_athenian_empire_431_BC-no.svg/220px-Map_athenian_empire_431_BC-no.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Map_athenian_empire_431_BC-no.svg) [Delian League](/wiki/Delian_League "Delian League") under the leadership of Athens before the [Peloponnesian War](/wiki/Peloponnesian_War "Peloponnesian War") in 431 BC

The decades that followed became known as the [Golden Age of Athenian democracy](/wiki/Fifth-century_Athens "Fifth-century Athens"), during which time Athens became the leading city of [Ancient Greece](/wiki/Ancient_Greece "Ancient Greece"), with its cultural achievements laying the foundations for [Western civilization](/wiki/Western_culture "Western culture").^[\[14\]](#cite_note-britannica-15)^^[\[15\]](#cite_note-bbc-16)^ The playwrights [Aeschylus](/wiki/Aeschylus "Aeschylus"), [Sophocles](/wiki/Sophocles "Sophocles") and [Euripides](/wiki/Euripides "Euripides") flourished in Athens during this time, as did the historians [Herodotus](/wiki/Herodotus "Herodotus") and [Thucydides](/wiki/Thucydides "Thucydides"), the physician [Hippocrates](/wiki/Hippocrates "Hippocrates"), and the philosopher [Socrates](/wiki/Socrates "Socrates"). Guided by [Pericles](/wiki/Pericles "Pericles"), who promoted the arts and fostered democracy, Athens embarked on an ambitious building program that saw the construction of the Acropolis of Athens (including the [Parthenon](/wiki/Parthenon "Parthenon")), as well as empire-building via the [Delian League](/wiki/Delian_League "Delian League"). Originally intended as an association of [Greek city-states](/wiki/Greek_city-state "Greek city-state") to continue the fight against the Persians, the league soon turned into a vehicle for Athens's own imperial ambitions. The resulting tensions brought about the [Peloponnesian War](/wiki/Peloponnesian_War "Peloponnesian War") (431--404 BC), in which Athens was defeated by its rival Sparta.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-42)^{#cite_ref-42}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/The_Parthenon_in_Athens.jpg/220px-The_Parthenon_in_Athens.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Parthenon_in_Athens.jpg) The [Parthenon](/wiki/Parthenon "Parthenon") on the [Acropolis](/wiki/Acropolis_of_Athens "Acropolis of Athens") hill of Athens dedicated to [Athena Parthenos](/wiki/Athena_Parthenos "Athena Parthenos")

By the mid-4th century BC, the northern Greek kingdom of [Macedon](/wiki/Macedon "Macedon") was becoming dominant in Athenian affairs. In 338 BC the armies of [Philip II](/wiki/Philip_II_of_Macedon "Philip II of Macedon") defeated an alliance of some of the Greek city-states including Athens and Thebes at the Battle of Chaeronea. Later, under Rome, Athens was given the status of a [free city](/wiki/Free_city_(classical_antiquity) "Free city (classical antiquity)") because of its widely admired schools. In the second century AD, the Roman emperor Hadrian, himself an Athenian citizen,^[\[42\]](#cite_note-43)^ ordered the construction of a library, a gymnasium, an aqueduct which is still in use, several temples and sanctuaries, a bridge and financed the completion of the [Temple of Olympian Zeus](/wiki/Temple_of_Olympian_Zeus,_Athens "Temple of Olympian Zeus, Athens").{#cite_ref-43}

In the early 4th century AD, the [Eastern Roman Empire](/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire "Eastern Roman Empire") began to be governed from [Constantinople](/wiki/Constantinople "Constantinople"), and with the construction and expansion of the imperial city, many of Athens's works of art were taken by the emperors to adorn it. The Empire became Christianized, and the use of [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") declined in favour of exclusive use of [Greek](/wiki/Medieval_Greek "Medieval Greek"); in the [Roman imperial period](/wiki/Roman_imperial_period_(chronology) "Roman imperial period (chronology)"), both languages had been used. In the later Roman period, Athens was ruled by the emperors continuing until the 13th century, its citizens identifying themselves as citizens of the Roman Empire ("*[Rhomaioi](/wiki/Rhomaioi "Rhomaioi")* "). The conversion of the empire from paganism to Christianity greatly affected Athens, resulting in reduced reverence for the city.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-tung-36)^ Ancient monuments such as the Parthenon, Erechtheion and the Hephaisteion (Theseion) were converted into churches. As the empire became increasingly anti-pagan, Athens became a provincial town and experienced fluctuating fortunes.{#cite_ref-tung_36-1}

The city remained an important center of learning, especially of [Neoplatonism](/wiki/Neoplatonism "Neoplatonism")---with notable pupils including [Gregory of Nazianzus](/wiki/Gregory_of_Nazianzus "Gregory of Nazianzus"), [Basil of Caesarea](/wiki/Basil_of_Caesarea "Basil of Caesarea") and emperor [Julian](/wiki/Julian_(emperor) "Julian (emperor)") ( 355--363)---and consequently a center of paganism. Christian items do not appear in the archaeological record until the early 5th century.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-ODB-44)^ The sack of the city by the [Herules](/wiki/Herules "Herules") in 267 and by the [Visigoths](/wiki/Visigoths "Visigoths") under their king [Alaric I](/wiki/Alaric_I "Alaric I") ( 395--410) in 396, however, dealt a heavy blow to the city's fabric and fortunes, and Athens was henceforth confined to a small fortified area that embraced a fraction of the ancient city.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-ODB-44)^ The emperor [Justinian I](/wiki/Justinian_I "Justinian I") ( 527--565) banned the teaching of philosophy by pagans in 529,^[\[44\]](#cite_note-45)^ an event whose impact on the city is much debated,^[\[43\]](#cite_note-ODB-44)^ but is generally taken to mark the end of the ancient history of Athens. Athens was sacked by the [Slavs](/wiki/Slavs "Slavs") in 582, but remained in imperial hands thereafter, as highlighted by the visit of the emperor [Constans II](/wiki/Constans_II "Constans II") ( 641--668) in 662/3 and its inclusion in the [Theme of Hellas](/wiki/Theme_of_Hellas "Theme of Hellas").^[\[43\]](#cite_note-ODB-44)^{#cite_ref-ODB_44-3}

### Middle Ages {#Middle_Ages}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Middle Ages")\]  
Further information: [Byzantine Greece](/wiki/Byzantine_Greece "Byzantine Greece") and [Duchy of Athens](/wiki/Duchy_of_Athens "Duchy of Athens")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/At_the_Byzantine_Monastery_of_Daphni_on_October_31%2C_2019.jpg/220px-At_the_Byzantine_Monastery_of_Daphni_on_October_31%2C_2019.jpg)](/wiki/File:At_the_Byzantine_Monastery_of_Daphni_on_October_31,_2019.jpg) The [Daphni Monastery](/wiki/Daphni_Monastery "Daphni Monastery"), an eleventh-century [Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine "Byzantine") monastery northwest of central Athens designated [UNESCO World Heritage Sites](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites "UNESCO World Heritage Sites")

The city was threatened by [Saracen](/wiki/Saracen "Saracen") raids in the 8th--9th centuries---in 896, Athens was raided and possibly occupied for a short period, an event which left some archaeological remains and elements of Arabic ornamentation in contemporary buildings^[\[45\]](#cite_note-EI2-46)^---but there is also evidence of a mosque existing in the city at the time.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-ODB-44)^ In the great dispute over [Byzantine Iconoclasm](/wiki/Byzantine_Iconoclasm "Byzantine Iconoclasm"), Athens is commonly held to have supported the [iconophile](/wiki/Iconophile "Iconophile") position, chiefly due to the role played by Empress [Irene of Athens](/wiki/Irene_of_Athens "Irene of Athens") in the ending of the first period of Iconoclasm at the [Second Council of Nicaea](/wiki/Second_Council_of_Nicaea "Second Council of Nicaea") in 787.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-ODB-44)^ A few years later, another Athenian, [Theophano](/wiki/Theophano_of_Athens "Theophano of Athens"), became empress as the wife of [Staurakios](/wiki/Staurakios "Staurakios") (r. 811--812).^[\[43\]](#cite_note-ODB-44)^{#cite_ref-ODB_44-6}

Invasion of the empire by the Turks after the [Battle of Manzikert](/wiki/Battle_of_Manzikert "Battle of Manzikert") in 1071, and the ensuing civil wars, largely passed the region by and Athens continued its provincial existence unharmed. When the Byzantine Empire was rescued by the resolute leadership of the three [Komnenos](/wiki/Komnenos "Komnenos") emperors [Alexios](/wiki/Alexios_I_Komnenos "Alexios I Komnenos"), [John](/wiki/John_II_Komnenos "John II Komnenos") and [Manuel](/wiki/Manuel_I_Komnenos "Manuel I Komnenos"), Attica and the rest of Greece prospered. Archaeological evidence tells us that the medieval town experienced a period of rapid and sustained growth, starting in the 11th century and continuing until the end of the 12th century.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Acropolis_Frankish_tower.jpg/220px-Acropolis_Frankish_tower.jpg)](/wiki/File:Acropolis_Frankish_tower.jpg) Photograph of the [Frankish Tower of the Acropolis of Athens](/wiki/Frankish_Tower_(Acropolis_of_Athens) "Frankish Tower (Acropolis of Athens)") in 1874, with the ruins of the [Propylaea](/wiki/Propylaea_(Acropolis_of_Athens) "Propylaea (Acropolis of Athens)") and view west over the Athenian plain towards [Mount Aigaleo](/wiki/Mount_Aigaleo "Mount Aigaleo") before it was demolished in 1875

The [Agora](/wiki/Ancient_Agora_of_Athens "Ancient Agora of Athens") (marketplace) had been deserted since late antiquity, began to be built over, and soon the town became an important centre for the production of soaps and dyes. The growth of the town attracted the [Venetians](/wiki/Venice "Venice"), and various other traders who frequented the ports of the Aegean, to Athens. This interest in trade appears to have further increased the economic prosperity of the town.

The 11th and 12th centuries were the Golden Age of [Byzantine art](/wiki/Byzantine_art "Byzantine art") in Athens. Almost all of the most important Middle Byzantine churches in and around Athens were built during these two centuries, and this reflects the growth of the town in general. However, this medieval prosperity was not to last. In 1204, the [Fourth Crusade](/wiki/Fourth_Crusade "Fourth Crusade") conquered Athens and the city was not recovered from the [Latins](/wiki/Roman_Catholicism "Roman Catholicism") before it was taken by the [Ottoman Turks](/wiki/Ottoman_Turks "Ottoman Turks"). It did not become Greek in government again until the 19th century.

From 1204 until 1458, Athens was ruled by Latins in three separate periods, following the [Crusades](/wiki/Crusades "Crusades"). The "Latins", or "[Franks](/wiki/Franks_(Crusaders) "Franks (Crusaders)")", were western Europeans and followers of the [Latin Church](/wiki/Latin_Church "Latin Church") brought to the [Eastern Mediterranean](/wiki/Eastern_Mediterranean "Eastern Mediterranean") during the Crusades. Along with rest of Byzantine Greece, Athens was part of the series of feudal [fiefs](/wiki/Fiefs "Fiefs"), similar to the [Crusader states](/wiki/Crusader_states "Crusader states") established in [Syria](/wiki/Syria_(region) "Syria (region)") and on [Cyprus](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Cyprus "Kingdom of Cyprus") after the [First Crusade](/wiki/First_Crusade "First Crusade"). This period is known as the *[Frankokratia](/wiki/Frankokratia "Frankokratia")*.  

### Ottoman Athens {#Ottoman_Athens}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Ottoman Athens")\]  
Main article: [Ottoman Greece](/wiki/Ottoman_Greece "Ottoman Greece")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Monastiraki_Square_in_Athens_%2830996716898%29.jpg/220px-Monastiraki_Square_in_Athens_%2830996716898%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Monastiraki_Square_in_Athens_(30996716898).jpg) [Tzistarakis Mosque](/wiki/Tzistarakis_Mosque "Tzistarakis Mosque"), an [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") mosque, built in 1759, in [Monastiraki](/wiki/Monastiraki "Monastiraki") Square [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Peytier_-_Mosque_in_the_Parthenon.jpg/220px-Peytier_-_Mosque_in_the_Parthenon.jpg)](/wiki/File:Peytier_-_Mosque_in_the_Parthenon.jpg) The second [Parthenon mosque](/wiki/Parthenon_mosque "Parthenon mosque") in the ruined [Parthenon](/wiki/Parthenon "Parthenon"), which was destroyed by a [Venetian bombardment in 1687](/wiki/Siege_of_the_Acropolis_(1687) "Siege of the Acropolis (1687)"), depicted by [Pierre Peytier](/wiki/Pierre_Peytier "Pierre Peytier") in the 1830s

The first [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") attack on Athens, which involved a short-lived occupation of the town, came in 1397, under the Ottoman generals [Yaqub Pasha](/w/index.php?title=Yaqub_Pasha&action=edit&redlink=1 "Yaqub Pasha (page does not exist)") and Timurtash.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-EI2-46)^ Finally, in 1458, Athens was captured by the Ottomans under the personal leadership of Sultan [Mehmed II](/wiki/Mehmed_II "Mehmed II").^[\[45\]](#cite_note-EI2-46)^ As the Ottoman Sultan rode into the city, he was greatly struck by the beauty of its ancient monuments and issued a *[firman](/wiki/Firman "Firman")* (imperial edict) forbidding their looting or destruction, on pain of death. The [Parthenon](/wiki/Parthenon "Parthenon") was converted into the [main mosque](/wiki/Parthenon_mosque "Parthenon mosque") of the city.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-tung-36)^{#cite_ref-tung_36-2}

Under Ottoman rule, Athens was denuded of any importance and its population severely declined, leaving it as a "small country town" ([Franz Babinger](/wiki/Franz_Babinger "Franz Babinger")).^[\[45\]](#cite_note-EI2-46)^ From the early 17th century, Athens came under the jurisdiction of the [Kizlar Agha](/wiki/Kizlar_Agha "Kizlar Agha"), the chief black eunuch of the [Sultan's harem](/wiki/Imperial_Harem "Imperial Harem"). The city had originally been granted by Sultan [Ahmed I](/wiki/Ahmed_I "Ahmed I") ( 1603--1617) to Basilica, one of his favourite concubines, who hailed from the city, in response of complaints of maladministration by the local governors. After her death, Athens came under the purview of the Kizlar Agha.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-47)^{#cite_ref-47}

The Turks began a practice of storing gunpowder and explosives in the Parthenon and [Propylaea](/wiki/Propylaea_(Acropolis_of_Athens) "Propylaea (Acropolis of Athens)"). In 1640, a lightning bolt struck the Propylaea, causing its destruction.^[\[47\]](#cite_note-48)^ In 1687, during the [Morean War](/wiki/Morean_War "Morean War"), the Acropolis [was besieged](/wiki/Siege_of_the_Acropolis_(1687) "Siege of the Acropolis (1687)") by the Venetians under [Francesco Morosini](/wiki/Francesco_Morosini "Francesco Morosini"), and the [temple of Athena Nike](/wiki/Temple_of_Athena_Nike "Temple of Athena Nike") was dismantled by the Ottomans to fortify the Parthenon. A shot fired during the bombardment of the Acropolis caused a powder magazine in the Parthenon to explode (26 September), and the building was severely damaged, giving it largely the appearance it has today. The Venetian occupation of Athens lasted for six months, and both the Venetians and the Ottomans participated in the looting of the Parthenon. One of its western pediments was removed, causing even more damage to the structure.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-tung-36)^^[\[45\]](#cite_note-EI2-46)^ During the Venetian occupation, the two mosques of the city were converted into Catholic and Protestant churches, but on 9 April 1688 the Venetians abandoned Athens again to the Ottomans.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-EI2-46)^{#cite_ref-EI2_46-5}  

### Modern history {#Modern_history}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Modern history")\]  
Main articles: [Greek War of Independence](/wiki/Greek_War_of_Independence "Greek War of Independence"), [Kingdom of Greece](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Greece "Kingdom of Greece"), and [Republic of Greece](/wiki/Republic_of_Greece "Republic of Greece")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Peter_von_Hess_-_The_Entry_of_King_Othon_of_Greece_in_Athens_-_WGA11387.jpg/220px-Peter_von_Hess_-_The_Entry_of_King_Othon_of_Greece_in_Athens_-_WGA11387.jpg)](/wiki/File:Peter_von_Hess_-_The_Entry_of_King_Othon_of_Greece_in_Athens_-_WGA11387.jpg) *[The Entry of King Otto of Greece into Athens](/wiki/The_Entry_of_King_Otto_of_Greece_into_Athens "The Entry of King Otto of Greece into Athens")* by [Peter von Hess](/wiki/Peter_von_Hess "Peter von Hess"), 1839

In 1822, a Greek insurgency captured the city, but it fell to the Ottomans again in 1826 (though Acropolis held till June 1827). Again the ancient monuments suffered badly. The Ottoman forces remained in possession until March 1833, when they withdrew.

Following the [Greek War of Independence](/wiki/Greek_War_of_Independence "Greek War of Independence") and the establishment of the [Greek Kingdom](/wiki/Greek_Kingdom "Greek Kingdom"), Athens was chosen to replace [Nafplio](/wiki/Nafplio "Nafplio") as the second capital of the newly independent Greek state in 1834, largely because of historical and sentimental reasons.^[\[48\]](#cite_note-49)^ At the time, after the extensive destruction it had suffered during the war of independence, it was reduced to a town of about 4,000 people (less than half its earlier population) in a loose swarm of houses along the foot of the Acropolis. The first [King of Greece](/wiki/King_of_Greece "King of Greece"), [King Otto](/wiki/Otto_of_Greece "Otto of Greece") of Bavaria, commissioned the architects [Stamatios Kleanthis](/wiki/Stamatios_Kleanthis "Stamatios Kleanthis") and [Eduard Schaubert](/wiki/Eduard_Schaubert "Eduard Schaubert") to design a modern city plan fit for the capital of a state.{#cite_ref-49}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Olympic_flame_at_opening_ceremony_2004.jpg/220px-Olympic_flame_at_opening_ceremony_2004.jpg)](/wiki/File:Olympic_flame_at_opening_ceremony_2004.jpg) The [Olympic Flame](/wiki/Olympic_Flame "Olympic Flame") at the [opening ceremony](/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony "2004 Summer Olympics opening ceremony") of the [2004 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics "2004 Summer Olympics")

The first modern city plan consisted of a triangle defined by the Acropolis, the ancient cemetery of [Kerameikos](/wiki/Kerameikos "Kerameikos") and the new palace of the Bavarian king (now housing the [Greek Parliament](/wiki/Greek_Parliament "Greek Parliament")), so as to highlight the continuity between modern and ancient Athens. Neoclassicism, the international style of this epoch, was the architectural style through which Bavarian, French and Greek architects such as Hansen, Klenze, Boulanger or Kaftantzoglou designed the first important public buildings of the new capital. In 1896, Athens hosted the first modern [Olympic Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games"). During the 1920s a number of [Greek refugees](/wiki/Greek_refugees "Greek refugees"), expelled from [Asia Minor](/wiki/Anatolia "Anatolia") after the [Greco-Turkish War](/wiki/Greco-Turkish_War_(1919%E2%80%931922) "Greco-Turkish War (1919–1922)") and [Population exchange between Greece and Turkey](/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_and_Turkey "Population exchange between Greece and Turkey"), swelled Athens's population; nevertheless it was mostly after [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and the [Civil War](/wiki/Greek_Civil_War "Greek Civil War") ended, during the 1950s and 1960s, that the population of the city exploded, and Athens experienced its greatest expansion.

In the 1980s, it became evident that smog from factories and an ever-increasing fleet of automobiles, as well as a lack of adequate free space due to congestion, had evolved into the city's most important challenge. The [Acropolis of Athens](/wiki/Acropolis_of_Athens "Acropolis of Athens") was inscribed as a [UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site "UNESCO World Heritage Site") in 1987, for its group of ancient Greek monumental ruins, including architectural masterpieces such as the [Parthenon](/wiki/Parthenon "Parthenon"). A series of anti-pollution measures taken by the city's authorities in the 1990s, combined with a substantial improvement of the city's infrastructure (including the [Attiki Odos](/wiki/Attiki_Odos "Attiki Odos") motorway, the expansion of the [Athens Metro](/wiki/Athens_Metro "Athens Metro"), and the new [Athens International Airport](/wiki/Athens_International_Airport "Athens International Airport")), considerably alleviated pollution and transformed Athens into a much more functional city. In 2004, Athens hosted the [2004 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics "2004 Summer Olympics"). Further urban improvements began in the 2020s along the coastal zone, including the [Hellenikon Park](/wiki/Hellenikon_Metropolitan_Park "Hellenikon Metropolitan Park") development and the Faliro Delta upgrade, adding to the [Stavros Niarchos Centre](/wiki/Stavros_Niarchos_Foundation_Cultural_Center "Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center").  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Geography")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Athens%2C_Greece_ESA24382014.jpeg/220px-Athens%2C_Greece_ESA24382014.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Athens,_Greece_ESA24382014.jpeg) The Athens Urban Area within the Attica Basin from space

Athens sprawls across the central plain of Attica that is often referred to as the **Athens Basin** or the **Attica Basin** ([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): Λεκανοπέδιο Αθηνών/Αττικής, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek "Romanization of Greek"): *Lekanopédio Athinón/Attikís*). The basin is bounded by four large mountains: [Mount Aigaleo](/wiki/Mount_Aigaleo "Mount Aigaleo") to the west, Mount [Parnitha](/wiki/Parnitha "Parnitha") to the north, [Mount Pentelicus](/wiki/Mount_Pentelicus "Mount Pentelicus") to the northeast and Mount [Hymettus](/wiki/Hymettus "Hymettus") to the east.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-Focus_on_Athens-50)^ Beyond Mount Aegaleo lies the [Thriasian plain](/wiki/Thriasian_plain "Thriasian plain"), which forms an extension of the central plain to the west. The [Saronic Gulf](/wiki/Saronic_Gulf "Saronic Gulf") lies to the southwest. Mount Parnitha is the tallest of the four mountains (1,413 m (4,636 ft)),^[\[50\]](#cite_note-51)^ and has been declared a [national park](/wiki/National_park "National park"). The Athens urban area spreads over 50 kilometres (31 mi) from [Agios Stefanos](/wiki/Agios_Stefanos,_Attica "Agios Stefanos, Attica") in the north to [Varkiza](/wiki/Varkiza "Varkiza") in the south. The city is located in the north temperate zone, 38 degrees north of the equator.{#cite_ref-51}

Athens is built around a large number of hills. [Lycabettus](/wiki/Mount_Lycabettus "Mount Lycabettus") is one of the tallest hills of the city proper and provides a view of the entire Attica Basin. The meteorology of Athens is deemed to be one of the most complex in the world because its mountains cause a [temperature inversion](/wiki/Inversion_(meteorology) "Inversion (meteorology)") phenomenon which, along with the Greek government's difficulties controlling industrial pollution, was responsible for the air pollution problems the city has faced.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-tung-36)^ This issue is not unique to Athens; for instance, Los Angeles and [Mexico City](/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City") also suffer from similar atmospheric inversion problems.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-tung-36)^{#cite_ref-tung_36-5}

The [Cephissus](/wiki/Cephissus_(Athenian_plain) "Cephissus (Athenian plain)") river, the [Ilisos](/wiki/Ilisos "Ilisos") and the [Eridanos](/wiki/Eridanos_(Athens) "Eridanos (Athens)") stream are the historical rivers of Athens.  

### Environment {#Environment}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Environment")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Smog_Athens.jpg/220px-Smog_Athens.jpg)](/wiki/File:Smog_Athens.jpg) Smog in Athens

By the late 1970s, the pollution of Athens had become so destructive that according to the then Greek [Minister of Culture](/wiki/Minister_for_Culture_(Greece) "Minister for Culture (Greece)"), Constantine Trypanis, "...the carved details on the five the caryatids of the [Erechtheum](/wiki/Erechtheum "Erechtheum") had seriously degenerated, while the face of the horseman on the Parthenon's west side was all but obliterated."^[\[51\]](#cite_note-52)^ A series of measures taken by the authorities of the city throughout the 1990s resulted in the improvement of air quality; the appearance of smog (or *nefos* as the Athenians used to call it) has become less common.{#cite_ref-52}

Measures taken by the Greek authorities throughout the 1990s have improved the quality of air over the Attica Basin. Nevertheless, air pollution still remains an issue for Athens, particularly during the hottest summer days. In late June 2007,^[\[52\]](#cite_note-outraged-53)^ the Attica region experienced a number of [brush fires](/wiki/2007_Greek_forest_fires "2007 Greek forest fires"),^[\[52\]](#cite_note-outraged-53)^ including a blaze that burned a significant portion of a large forested national park in [Mount Parnitha](/wiki/Parnitha "Parnitha"),^[\[53\]](#cite_note-ypexode-54)^ considered critical to maintaining a better air quality in Athens all year round.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-outraged-53)^ Damage to the park has led to worries over a stalling in the improvement of air quality in the city.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-outraged-53)^{#cite_ref-outraged_53-3}

The major waste management efforts undertaken in the last decade (particularly the plant built on the small island of Psytalia) have greatly improved [water quality](/wiki/Water_quality "Water quality") in the Saronic Gulf, and the coastal waters of Athens are now accessible again to swimmers.  

#### Parks and zoos {#Parks_and_zoos}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Parks and zoos")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Pedion_Areos08_25_05_623000.jpeg/220px-Pedion_Areos08_25_05_623000.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Pedion_Areos08_25_05_623000.jpeg) The [Pedion tou Areos](/wiki/Pedion_tou_Areos "Pedion tou Areos") park [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/20140410_60_Athens_National_Gardens_%2813824726745%29.jpg/220px-20140410_60_Athens_National_Gardens_%2813824726745%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:20140410_60_Athens_National_Gardens_(13824726745).jpg) The entrance of the [National Gardens](/wiki/National_Garden_of_Athens "National Garden of Athens"), commissioned by [Queen Amalia](/wiki/Amalia_of_Oldenburg "Amalia of Oldenburg") in 1838 and completed by 1840

[Parnitha](/wiki/Parnitha "Parnitha") National Park is punctuated by well-marked paths, gorges, springs, torrents and caves dotting the protected area. Hiking and mountain-biking in all four mountains are popular outdoor activities for residents of the city. The [National Garden of Athens](/wiki/National_Garden_of_Athens "National Garden of Athens") was completed in 1840 and is a green refuge of 15.5 hectares in the centre of the Greek capital. It is to be found between the Parliament and [Zappeion](/wiki/Zappeion "Zappeion") buildings, the latter of which maintains its own garden of seven hectares. Parts of the City Centre have been redeveloped under a masterplan called the *Unification of Archeological Sites of Athens* , which has also gathered funding from the EU to help enhance the project.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-EUfund-55)^^[\[55\]](#cite_note-56)^ The landmark [Dionysiou Areopagitou Street](/wiki/Dionysiou_Areopagitou_Street "Dionysiou Areopagitou Street") has been pedestrianised, forming a scenic route. The route starts from the [Temple of Olympian Zeus](/wiki/Temple_of_Olympian_Zeus_(Athens) "Temple of Olympian Zeus (Athens)") at Vasilissis Olgas Avenue, continues under the southern slopes of the Acropolis near [Plaka](/wiki/Plaka "Plaka"), and finishes just beyond the [Temple of Hephaestus](/wiki/Temple_of_Hephaestus "Temple of Hephaestus") in [Thiseio](/wiki/Thiseio "Thiseio"). The route in its entirety provides visitors with views of the Parthenon and the [Agora](/wiki/Ancient_Agora_of_Athens "Ancient Agora of Athens") (the meeting point of ancient Athenians), away from the busy City Centre.{#cite_ref-56}

The hills of Athens also provide green space. [Lycabettus](/wiki/Mount_Lycabettus "Mount Lycabettus"), [Philopappos hill](/wiki/Philopappos_Monument "Philopappos Monument") and the area around it, including [Pnyx](/wiki/Pnyx "Pnyx") and [Ardettos hill](/w/index.php?title=Ardettos_hill&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ardettos hill (page does not exist)"), are planted with pines and other trees, with the character of a small forest rather than typical metropolitan parkland. Also to be found is the [Pedion tou Areos](/wiki/Pedion_tou_Areos "Pedion tou Areos") (*Field of Mars* ) of 27.7 hectares, near the [National Archaeological Museum](/wiki/National_Archaeological_Museum,_Athens "National Archaeological Museum, Athens"). Athens' largest zoo is the [Attica Zoological Park](/wiki/Attica_Zoological_Park "Attica Zoological Park"), a 20-hectare (49-acre) private zoo located in the suburb of Spata. The zoo is home to around 2000 animals representing 400 species, and is open 365 days a year. Smaller zoos exist within public gardens or parks, such as the zoo within the National Garden of Athens.  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Climate")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Athens_and_Mount_Lycabettus_from_the_Areopagus_on_July_22%2C_2019.jpg/220px-Athens_and_Mount_Lycabettus_from_the_Areopagus_on_July_22%2C_2019.jpg)](/wiki/File:Athens_and_Mount_Lycabettus_from_the_Areopagus_on_July_22,_2019.jpg) Sunrise in Athens

Athens has a hot-summer [Mediterranean climate](/wiki/Mediterranean_climate "Mediterranean climate") ([Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Csa* ). The climate in Athens can be considered warmer than some cities that are similar or even less distant from the equator such as Seoul, Melbourne, Buenos Aires, Cape Town and Norfolk (Virginia, US). According to the meteorological station near the city center which is operated by the [National Observatory of Athens](/wiki/National_Observatory_of_Athens "National Observatory of Athens"), the downtown area has simple mean annual temperature of 19.2 °C (66.6 °F) while parts of the urban agglomeration may reach up to 19.8 °C (67.6 °F), being affected by the [urban heat island](/wiki/Urban_heat_island "Urban heat island") effect.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-Climate_Atlas_of_Greece-57)^ Athens receives about 433.1 millimetres (17.05 in) of precipitation per year, largely concentrated during the colder half of the year with the remaining rainfall falling sparsely, mainly during thunderstorms. [Fog](/wiki/Fog "Fog") is rare in the city center, but somewhat more frequent in areas to the east, close to mount [Hymettus](/wiki/Hymettus "Hymettus").^[\[57\]](#cite_note-Practical_Information_About_Athens-58)^{#cite_ref-Practical_Information_About_Athens_58-0}

The southern section of the [Athens metropolitan area](/wiki/Athens_metropolitan_area "Athens metropolitan area") (i.e., [Elliniko](/wiki/Elliniko "Elliniko"), [Athens Riviera](/wiki/Athens_Riviera "Athens Riviera")) lies in the transitional zone between [Mediterranean](/wiki/Mediterranean_climate "Mediterranean climate") (*Csa* ) and hot [semi-arid climate](/wiki/Semi-arid_climate "Semi-arid climate") (*BSh* ), with its port-city of [Piraeus](/wiki/Piraeus "Piraeus") being the most extreme example, receiving just 331.9 millimetres (13.07 in) per year. The areas to the south generally see less extreme temperature variations as their climate is moderated by the [Saronic gulf](/wiki/Saronic_Gulf "Saronic Gulf").^[\[58\]](#cite_note-59)^ The northern part of the city (i.e., [Kifissia](/wiki/Kifissia "Kifissia")), owing to its higher elevation, features moderately lower temperatures and slightly increased precipitation year-round. The generally dry climate of the Athens basin compared to the precipitation amounts seen in a typical [Mediterranean climate](/wiki/Mediterranean_climate "Mediterranean climate") is due to the [rain shadow](/wiki/Rain_shadow "Rain shadow") effect caused by the [Pindus](/wiki/Pindus "Pindus") mountain range and the [Dirfys](/wiki/Dirfi "Dirfi") and [Parnitha](/wiki/Parnitha "Parnitha") mountains, substantially drying the westerly^[\[59\]](#cite_note-60)^ and northerly^[\[57\]](#cite_note-Practical_Information_About_Athens-58)^ winds respectively.{#cite_ref-Practical_Information_About_Athens_58-1}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/View_of_the_Ancient_Agora_of_Athens_from_Apostolou_Pavlou_Pedestrian_Street_on_February_16%2C_2021.jpg/220px-View_of_the_Ancient_Agora_of_Athens_from_Apostolou_Pavlou_Pedestrian_Street_on_February_16%2C_2021.jpg)](/wiki/File:View_of_the_Ancient_Agora_of_Athens_from_Apostolou_Pavlou_Pedestrian_Street_on_February_16,_2021.jpg) Snowfall in Athens on 16 February 2021

Snowfall is not very common. It usually does not cause heavy disruption to daily life, in contrast to the northern parts of the city, where [blizzards](/wiki/Blizzard "Blizzard") occur on a somewhat more regular basis. The most recent examples include the snowstorms of 16 February 2021^[\[60\]](#cite_note-61)^ and 24 January 2022,^[\[61\]](#cite_note-62)^ when the entire urban area was blanketed in snow.{#cite_ref-62}

Athens may get particularly hot in the summer, owing partly to the strong [urban heat island](/wiki/Urban_heat_island "Urban heat island") effect characterizing the city.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-63)^ In fact, Athens has been referred to as the hottest city in [mainland Europe](/wiki/Mainland_Europe "Mainland Europe"),^[\[63\]](#cite_note-Athens_will_be_the_first_European_city_to_appoint_a_chief_heat_officer-64)^ and is the first city in Europe to appoint a chief heat officer to deal with severe [heat waves](/wiki/Heat_wave "Heat wave").^[\[64\]](#cite_note-65)^ [Temperatures of 47.5°C](/wiki/List_of_extreme_temperatures_in_Greece "List of extreme temperatures in Greece") have been reported in several locations of the metropolitan area, including within the urban agglomeration. [Metropolitan Athens](/wiki/Athens_metropolitan_area "Athens metropolitan area") was until 2021 the holder of the [World Meteorological Organization](/wiki/World_Meteorological_Organization "World Meteorological Organization") record for the highest temperature ever recorded in Europe with 48.0 °C (118.4 °F) which was recorded in the areas of [Elefsina](/wiki/Elefsina "Elefsina") and [Tatoi](/wiki/Tatoi_Palace "Tatoi Palace") on 10 July 1977.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-66)^^[\[66\]](#cite_note-67)^{#cite_ref-67}

Administration {#Administration}
--------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Administration")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/%CE%94%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%81%CF%87%CE%B5%CE%AF%CE%BF_%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CF%8E%CE%BD_9734.jpg/220px-%CE%94%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%81%CF%87%CE%B5%CE%AF%CE%BF_%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CF%8E%CE%BD_9734.jpg)](/wiki/File:%CE%94%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%81%CF%87%CE%B5%CE%AF%CE%BF_%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CF%8E%CE%BD_9734.jpg) Athens City Hall [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Ancien_Palais_Royal_-_Ath%C3%A8nes_%28GRA1%29_-_2022-03-26_-_1.jpg/220px-Ancien_Palais_Royal_-_Ath%C3%A8nes_%28GRA1%29_-_2022-03-26_-_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ancien_Palais_Royal_-_Ath%C3%A8nes_(GRA1)_-_2022-03-26_-_1.jpg) [Old Royal Palace](/wiki/Old_Royal_Palace "Old Royal Palace")

Athens became the capital of Greece in 1834, following [Nafplion](/wiki/Nafplion "Nafplion"), which was the provisional capital from 1829. The municipality (city) of Athens is also the capital of the [Attica](/wiki/Attica_(region) "Attica (region)") region. The term *Athens* can refer either to the municipality of Athens, to Greater Athens or urban area, or to the entire Athens Metropolitan Area.

The large **city centre** ([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): Κέντρο της Αθήνας, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek "Romanization of Greek"): *Kéntro tis Athínas*) of the Greek capital falls directly within the **Municipality of Athens** ([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): Δήμος Αθηναίων, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek "Romanization of Greek"): *Dímos Athinaíon*), which is the largest in population size in Greece and forms the core of the Athens urban area, followed by the **Municipality of [Piraeus](/wiki/Piraeus "Piraeus")**, which forms a significant city centre on its own within the Athens urban area and it is the second largest in population size within it.  

### Athens Urban Area {#Athens_Urban_Area}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Athens Urban Area")\]

The **Athens Urban Area** ([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): Πολεοδομικό Συγκρότημα Αθηνών, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek "Romanization of Greek"): *Poleodomikó Synkrótima Athinón*), also known as **Urban Area of the Capital** ([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): Πολεοδομικό Συγκρότημα Πρωτεύουσας, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek "Romanization of Greek"): *Poleodomikó Synkrótima Protévousas*) or **Greater Athens** ([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): Ευρύτερη Αθήνα, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek "Romanization of Greek"): *Evrýteri Athína*),^[\[76\]](#cite_note-77)^ today consists of 40 municipalities: 35 of them divided in four regional units ([Central Athens](/wiki/Central_Athens_(regional_unit) "Central Athens (regional unit)"), [North Athens](/wiki/North_Athens_(regional_unit) "North Athens (regional unit)"), [West Athens](/wiki/West_Athens_(regional_unit) "West Athens (regional unit)"), [South Athens](/wiki/South_Athens_(regional_unit) "South Athens (regional unit)")), and a further 5 municipalities which make up the [regional unit of Piraeus](/wiki/Piraeus_(regional_unit) "Piraeus (regional unit)"). The Athens urban area spans over 412 km^2^ (159 sq mi),^[\[77\]](#cite_note-Kallikratis-78)^ with a population of 3,059,764 people as of 2021.{#cite_ref-Kallikratis_78-0}

### Athens metropolitan area {#Athens_metropolitan_area}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Athens metropolitan area")\]  
Main article: [Athens metropolitan area](/wiki/Athens_metropolitan_area "Athens metropolitan area")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Athens_Metropolitan_Region.svg/220px-Athens_Metropolitan_Region.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Athens_Metropolitan_Region.svg) [Athens metropolitan area](/wiki/Athens_metropolitan_area "Athens metropolitan area")

The Athens metropolitan area spans 2,928.717 km^2^ (1,131 sq mi) within the [Attica region](/wiki/Attica_(region) "Attica (region)") and includes a total of 58 municipalities, which are organized in seven regional units (those outlined above, along with [East Attica](/wiki/East_Attica "East Attica") and [West Attica](/wiki/West_Attica "West Attica")), having reached a population of 3,638,281 according to the 2021 census.^[\[4\]](#cite_note-census21-4)^ Athens and Piraeus municipalities serve as the two metropolitan centres of the Athens Metropolitan Area.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-79)^ There are also some inter-municipal centres serving specific areas. For example, [Kifissia](/wiki/Kifissia "Kifissia") and [Glyfada](/wiki/Glyfada "Glyfada") serve as inter-municipal centres for northern and southern suburbs respectively.{#cite_ref-79}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/%CE%92%CE%AF%CE%BB%CE%B1_%CE%91%CF%84%CE%BB%CE%B1%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%AF%CF%82_3473.jpg/220px-%CE%92%CE%AF%CE%BB%CE%B1_%CE%91%CF%84%CE%BB%CE%B1%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%AF%CF%82_3473.jpg)](/wiki/File:%CE%92%CE%AF%CE%BB%CE%B1_%CE%91%CF%84%CE%BB%CE%B1%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%AF%CF%82_3473.jpg) View of Vila Atlantis, in [Kifissia](/wiki/Kifissia "Kifissia"), designed by [Ernst Ziller](/wiki/Ernst_Ziller "Ernst Ziller") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Alimos_-_panoramio_%2833%29.jpg/220px-Alimos_-_panoramio_%2833%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Alimos_-_panoramio_(33).jpg) Beach in the southern suburb of [Alimos](/wiki/Alimos "Alimos"), one of the many beaches in the southern coast of Athens

The [Athens Metropolitan Area](/wiki/Athens_Metropolitan_Area,_Greece "Athens Metropolitan Area, Greece") consists of 58^[\[79\]](#cite_note-statistics1-80)^ densely populated municipalities, sprawling around the [Municipality of Athens](/wiki/Municipality_of_Athens "Municipality of Athens") (the City Centre) in virtually all directions. For the Athenians, all the urban municipalities surrounding the City Centre are called suburbs. According to their geographic location in relation to the City of Athens, the suburbs are divided into four zones; the northern suburbs (including [Agios Stefanos](/wiki/Agios_Stefanos,_Attica "Agios Stefanos, Attica"), [Dionysos](/wiki/Dionysos,_Greece "Dionysos, Greece"), [Ekali](/wiki/Ekali "Ekali"), [Nea Erythraia](/wiki/Nea_Erythraia "Nea Erythraia"), [Kifissia](/wiki/Kifissia "Kifissia"), [Kryoneri](/wiki/Kryoneri,_Attica "Kryoneri, Attica"), [Maroussi](/wiki/Marousi "Marousi"), [Pefki](/wiki/Pefki "Pefki"), [Lykovrysi](/wiki/Lykovrysi "Lykovrysi"), [Metamorfosi](/wiki/Metamorfosi "Metamorfosi"), [Nea Ionia](/wiki/Nea_Ionia "Nea Ionia"), [Nea Filadelfeia](/wiki/Nea_Filadelfeia "Nea Filadelfeia"), [Irakleio](/wiki/Irakleio,_Attica "Irakleio, Attica"), [Vrilissia](/wiki/Vrilissia "Vrilissia"), [Melissia](/wiki/Melissia "Melissia"), [Penteli](/wiki/Penteli,_Greece "Penteli, Greece"), [Chalandri](/wiki/Chalandri "Chalandri"), [Agia Paraskevi](/wiki/Agia_Paraskevi "Agia Paraskevi"), [Gerakas](/wiki/Gerakas "Gerakas"), [Pallini](/wiki/Pallini "Pallini"), [Galatsi](/wiki/Galatsi "Galatsi"), [Psychiko](/wiki/Psychiko "Psychiko") and [Filothei](/wiki/Filothei "Filothei")); the southern suburbs (including [Alimos](/wiki/Alimos "Alimos"), [Nea Smyrni](/wiki/Nea_Smyrni "Nea Smyrni"), [Moschato](/wiki/Moschato "Moschato"), [Tavros](/wiki/Tavros "Tavros"), [Agios Ioannis Renti](/wiki/Agios_Ioannis_Renti "Agios Ioannis Renti"), [Kallithea](/wiki/Kallithea "Kallithea"), [Piraeus](/wiki/Piraeus "Piraeus"), [Agios Dimitrios](/wiki/Agios_Dimitrios "Agios Dimitrios"), [Palaio Faliro](/wiki/Palaio_Faliro "Palaio Faliro"), [Elliniko](/wiki/Ellinikon "Ellinikon"), [Glyfada](/wiki/Glyfada "Glyfada"), [Lagonisi](/wiki/Lagonisi "Lagonisi"), [Saronida](/wiki/Saronida "Saronida"), [Argyroupoli](/wiki/Argyroupoli "Argyroupoli"), [Ilioupoli](/wiki/Ilioupoli "Ilioupoli"), [Varkiza](/wiki/Varkiza "Varkiza"), [Voula](/wiki/Voula "Voula"), [Vari](/wiki/Vari "Vari") and [Vouliagmeni](/wiki/Vouliagmeni "Vouliagmeni")); the eastern suburbs (including [Zografou](/wiki/Zografou "Zografou"), [Dafni](/wiki/Dafni,_Attica "Dafni, Attica"), [Vyronas](/wiki/Vyronas "Vyronas"), [Kaisariani](/wiki/Kaisariani "Kaisariani"), [Cholargos](/wiki/Cholargos "Cholargos") and [Papagou](/wiki/Papagou "Papagou")); and the western suburbs (including [Peristeri](/wiki/Peristeri "Peristeri"), [Ilion](/wiki/Ilion,_Greece "Ilion, Greece"), [Egaleo](/wiki/Egaleo "Egaleo"), [Koridallos](/wiki/Koridallos "Koridallos"), [Agia Varvara](/wiki/Agia_Varvara "Agia Varvara"), [Keratsini](/wiki/Keratsini "Keratsini"), [Perama](/wiki/Perama "Perama"), [Nikaia](/wiki/Nikaia "Nikaia"), [Drapetsona](/wiki/Drapetsona "Drapetsona"), [Chaidari](/wiki/Chaidari "Chaidari"), [Petroupoli](/wiki/Petroupoli "Petroupoli"), [Agioi Anargyroi](/wiki/Agioi_Anargyroi "Agioi Anargyroi"), [Ano Liosia](/wiki/Ano_Liosia "Ano Liosia"), [Aspropyrgos](/wiki/Aspropyrgos "Aspropyrgos"), [Eleusina](/wiki/Eleusina "Eleusina"), [Acharnes](/wiki/Acharnes "Acharnes") and [Kamatero](/wiki/Kamatero "Kamatero")).{#cite_ref-statistics1_80-0}

The Athens city coastline, extending from the major commercial port of [Piraeus](/wiki/Piraeus "Piraeus") to the southernmost suburb of [Varkiza](/wiki/Varkiza "Varkiza") for some 25 km (20 mi),^[\[80\]](#cite_note-81)^ is also connected to the City Centre by tram.{#cite_ref-81}

In the northern suburb of Maroussi, the upgraded main [Olympic Complex](/wiki/Athens_Olympic_Sports_Complex "Athens Olympic Sports Complex") (known by its Greek acronym OAKA) dominates the skyline. The area has been redeveloped according to a design by the Spanish architect [Santiago Calatrava](/wiki/Santiago_Calatrava "Santiago Calatrava"), with steel arches, landscaped gardens, fountains, futuristic glass, and a landmark new blue glass roof which was added to the main stadium. A second Olympic complex, next to the sea at the beach of Palaio Faliro, also features modern stadia, shops and an elevated esplanade. Work is underway to transform the grounds of the old Athens Airport -- named [Elliniko](/wiki/Ellinikon_International_Airport "Ellinikon International Airport") -- in the southern suburbs, into one of the largest landscaped parks in Europe, to be named the [Hellenikon Metropolitan Park](/wiki/Hellenikon_Metropolitan_Park "Hellenikon Metropolitan Park").^[\[81\]](#cite_note-82)^{#cite_ref-82}

Many of the southern suburbs (such as [Alimos](/wiki/Alimos "Alimos"), [Palaio Faliro](/wiki/Palaio_Faliro "Palaio Faliro"), [Elliniko](/wiki/Ellinikon "Ellinikon"), [Glyfada](/wiki/Glyfada "Glyfada"), [Voula](/wiki/Voula "Voula"), [Vouliagmeni](/wiki/Vouliagmeni "Vouliagmeni") and [Varkiza](/wiki/Varkiza "Varkiza")) known as the [Athens Riviera](/wiki/Athens_Riviera "Athens Riviera"), host a number of sandy beaches, most of which are operated by the [Greek National Tourism Organisation](/wiki/Greek_National_Tourism_Organization "Greek National Tourism Organization") and require an entrance fee. Casinos operate on both Mount Parnitha ([Regency Casino Mont Parnes](/wiki/Regency_Casino_Mont_Parnes "Regency Casino Mont Parnes")), some 25 km (16 mi)^[\[82\]](#cite_note-83)^ from downtown Athens (accessible by car or cable car), and the nearby town of [Loutraki](/wiki/Loutraki "Loutraki") (accessible by car via the Athens -- [Corinth](/wiki/Corinth "Corinth") National Highway, or the [Athens Suburban Railway](/wiki/Athens_Suburban_Railway "Athens Suburban Railway")).{#cite_ref-83}

### Twin towns -- sister cities {#Twin_towns_.E2.80.93_sister_cities}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Twin towns – sister cities")\]  
Main article: [List of twin towns and sister cities in Greece](/wiki/List_of_twin_towns_and_sister_cities_in_Greece "List of twin towns and sister cities in Greece")

The concept of a [partner city](/wiki/Sister_city "Sister city") is used under different names in different countries, but they mean the same thing, that two cities in different countries assist each other as partners. Athens has quite a number of partners, whether as a "twin", a "sister", or a "partner."  

Demographics {#Demographics}
----------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Demographics")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Population_Density_in_Athens.PNG/220px-Population_Density_in_Athens.PNG)](/wiki/File:Population_Density_in_Athens.PNG) Athens population distribution

The Municipality of Athens has an official population of 643,452 people (in 2021).^[\[4\]](#cite_note-census21-4)^ According to the [2021 Population and Housing Census](/wiki/2021_Greek_census "2021 Greek census"), The four regional units that make up the former Athens prefecture have a combined population of 2,611,713 . They together with the [regional unit of Piraeus](/wiki/Piraeus_(regional_unit) "Piraeus (regional unit)") (sometimes referred to as Greater Piraeus) make up the dense Athens Urban Area or Greater Athens which reaches a total population of 3,059,764 inhabitants (in 2021).^[\[4\]](#cite_note-census21-4)^{#cite_ref-census21_4-5}

The municipality (Center) of Athens is the [most populous in Greece](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Greece "List of cities in Greece"), with a population of 643,452 people (in 2021)^[\[4\]](#cite_note-census21-4)^ and an area of 38.96 km^2^ (15.04 sq mi),^[\[7\]](#cite_note-stat01-8)^ forming the core of the Athens Urban Area within the Attica Basin. The incumbent [Mayor of Athens](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Athens "List of mayors of Athens") is Charis Doukas of PASOK. The municipality is divided into seven municipal districts which are mainly used for administrative purposes.^[\[83\]](#cite_note-statistics-84)^{#cite_ref-statistics_84-0}

For the Athenians the most popular way of dividing the downtown is through its neighbourhoods such as [Pagkrati](/wiki/Pangrati "Pangrati"), [Ampelokipoi](/wiki/Ambelokipi,_Athens "Ambelokipi, Athens"), [Goudi](/wiki/Goudi "Goudi"), [Exarcheia](/wiki/Exarcheia "Exarcheia"), [Patisia](/wiki/Patisia "Patisia"), [Ilisia](/wiki/Ilisia,_Athens "Ilisia, Athens"), [Petralona](/wiki/Petralona "Petralona"), [Plaka](/wiki/Plaka "Plaka"), [Anafiotika](/wiki/Anafiotika "Anafiotika"), [Koukaki](/wiki/Koukaki "Koukaki"), [Kolonaki](/wiki/Kolonaki "Kolonaki") and [Kypseli](/wiki/Kypseli,_Athens "Kypseli, Athens"), each with its own distinct history and characteristics.

[Romani people](/wiki/Romani_people "Romani people") are concentrated in Acharnes, Ano Liosia, Agia Varvara, Zefeiri and Kamatero.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-85)^{#cite_ref-85}

There is a large Albanian community in Athens.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-86)^{#cite_ref-86}  

### Metropolitan Area {#Metropolitan_Area}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Metropolitan Area")\]

The Athens Metropolitan Area, with an area of 2,928.717 km^2^ (1,131 sq mi) and inhabited by 3,744,059 people in 2021,^[\[4\]](#cite_note-census21-4)^ consists of the Athens Urban Area with the addition of the towns and villages of [East](/wiki/East_Attica "East Attica") and [West Attica](/wiki/West_Attica "West Attica"), which surround the dense urban area of the Greek capital. It actually sprawls over the whole peninsula of Attica, which is the best part of the [region of Attica](/wiki/Attica_(region) "Attica (region)"), excluding the [islands](/wiki/Islands_(regional_unit) "Islands (regional unit)").{#cite_ref-census21_4-7}

### Safety {#Safety}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Safety")\]

Athens ranks in the lowest percentage for the risk on frequency and severity of terrorist attacks according to the EU Global Terrorism Database (EIU 2007--2016 calculations). The city also ranked 35th in Digital Security, 21st on Health Security, 29th on Infrastructure Security and 41st on Personal Security globally in a 2017 The [Economist Intelligence Unit](/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit "Economist Intelligence Unit") report.^[\[86\]](#cite_note-87)^ It also ranks as a very safe city (39th globally out of 162 cities overall) on the ranking of the safest and most dangerous countries.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-88)^ As November 2024 the crime index from [Numbeo](/wiki/Numbeo "Numbeo") places Athens at 55.40 (moderate), while its safety index is at 44.60.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-89)^^[\[89\]](#cite_note-90)^ According to a [Mercer](/wiki/Mercer_(consulting_firm) "Mercer (consulting firm)") 2019 Quality of Living Survey, Athens ranks 89th on the Mercer Quality of Living Survey ranking.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-91)^{#cite_ref-91}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Economy")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/46/OTE_Headquarters_%2820-12-2021%29.png/220px-OTE_Headquarters_%2820-12-2021%29.png)](/wiki/File:OTE_Headquarters_(20-12-2021).png) [OTE](/wiki/OTE "OTE") headquarters in [Marousi](/wiki/Marousi "Marousi"), the largest [technology company](/wiki/Technology_company "Technology company") in Greece [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/%CE%9C%CE%AD%CE%B3%CE%B1%CF%81%CE%BF_%CE%93%CE%B5%CF%89%CF%81%CE%B3%CE%AF%CE%BF%CF%85_%CE%A3%CF%84%CF%81%CE%AC%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85_-_%CE%95%CE%B8%CE%BD%CE%B9%CE%BA%CE%AE_%CE%A4%CF%81%CE%AC%CF%80%CE%B5%CE%B6%CE%B1_1249.jpg/220px-%CE%9C%CE%AD%CE%B3%CE%B1%CF%81%CE%BF_%CE%93%CE%B5%CF%89%CF%81%CE%B3%CE%AF%CE%BF%CF%85_%CE%A3%CF%84%CF%81%CE%AC%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85_-_%CE%95%CE%B8%CE%BD%CE%B9%CE%BA%CE%AE_%CE%A4%CF%81%CE%AC%CF%80%CE%B5%CE%B6%CE%B1_1249.jpg)](/wiki/File:%CE%9C%CE%AD%CE%B3%CE%B1%CF%81%CE%BF_%CE%93%CE%B5%CF%89%CF%81%CE%B3%CE%AF%CE%BF%CF%85_%CE%A3%CF%84%CF%81%CE%AC%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85_-_%CE%95%CE%B8%CE%BD%CE%B9%CE%BA%CE%AE_%CE%A4%CF%81%CE%AC%CF%80%CE%B5%CE%B6%CE%B1_1249.jpg) [National Bank of Greece](/wiki/National_Bank_of_Greece "National Bank of Greece"), the largest Greek bank by total assets^[\[91\]](#cite_note-92)^^[\[92\]](#cite_note-93)^ [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Ermou_Street_in_the_evening._In_the_distance_the_Byzantine_Church_of_Panagia_Kapnikarea.jpg/220px-Ermou_Street_in_the_evening._In_the_distance_the_Byzantine_Church_of_Panagia_Kapnikarea.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ermou_Street_in_the_evening._In_the_distance_the_Byzantine_Church_of_Panagia_Kapnikarea.jpg) [Ermou street](/wiki/Ermou_Street_(Athens) "Ermou Street (Athens)"), the main commercial street of Athens

Athens is the [financial capital](/wiki/Financial_centre "Financial centre") of Greece. According to data from 2014, Athens as a metropolitan economic area produced US$130 billion as GDP in [PPP](/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity "Purchasing power parity"), which consists of nearly half of the production for the whole country. Athens was ranked 102nd in that year's list of global economic metropolises, while GDP per capita for the same year was 32,000 [US dollars](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar").^[\[93\]](#cite_note-94)^{#cite_ref-94}

Athens is one of the major economic centres in south-eastern Europe and is considered a regional economic power. The port of Piraeus, where big investments by [COSCO](/wiki/COSCO_Shipping "COSCO Shipping") have already been delivered during the recent decade, the completion of the new Cargo Centre in Thriasion,^[\[94\]](#cite_note-95)^ the [expansion of the Athens Metro](/wiki/Line_4_(Athens_Metro) "Line 4 (Athens Metro)") and the [Athens Tram](/wiki/Athens_Tram "Athens Tram"), as well as the [Hellenikon metropolitan park](/wiki/Hellenikon_Metropolitan_Park "Hellenikon Metropolitan Park") redevelopment in Elliniko and other urban projects, are the economic landmarks of the upcoming years.{#cite_ref-95}

Prominent Greek companies such as [Hellas Sat](/wiki/Hellas_Sat "Hellas Sat"), [Hellenic Aerospace Industry](/wiki/Hellenic_Aerospace_Industry "Hellenic Aerospace Industry"), [Mytilineos Holdings](/wiki/Mytilineos_Holdings "Mytilineos Holdings"), [Titan Cement](/wiki/Titan_Cement "Titan Cement"), [Hellenic Petroleum](/wiki/Hellenic_Petroleum "Hellenic Petroleum"), [Papadopoulos E.J.](/wiki/Papadopoulos_(biscuits) "Papadopoulos (biscuits)"), [Folli Follie](/wiki/Folli_Follie "Folli Follie"), [Jumbo S.A.](/wiki/Jumbo_S.A. "Jumbo S.A."), [OPAP](/wiki/OPAP "OPAP"), and [Cosmote](/wiki/Cosmote "Cosmote") have their headquarters in the metropolitan area of Athens. Multinational companies such as [Ericsson](/wiki/Ericsson "Ericsson"), [Sony](/wiki/Sony "Sony"), [Siemens](/wiki/Siemens "Siemens"), [Motorola](/wiki/Motorola "Motorola"), [Samsung](/wiki/Samsung "Samsung"), [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft"), [Teleperformance](/wiki/Teleperformance "Teleperformance"), [Novartis](/wiki/Novartis "Novartis"), [Mondelez](/wiki/Mondelez "Mondelez") and [Coca-Cola](/wiki/Coca-Cola "Coca-Cola") also have their regional research and development headquarters in the city. The banking sector is represented by [National Bank of Greece](/wiki/National_Bank_of_Greece "National Bank of Greece"), [Alpha Bank](/wiki/Alpha_Bank "Alpha Bank"), [Eurobank](/wiki/Eurobank_Ergasias "Eurobank Ergasias"), and [Piraeus Bank](/wiki/Piraeus_Bank "Piraeus Bank"), while the [Bank of Greece](/wiki/Bank_of_Greece "Bank of Greece") is also situated in the City Centre. The [Athens Stock Exchange](/wiki/Athens_Exchange "Athens Exchange") was severely hit by the [Greek government-debt crisis](/wiki/Greek_government-debt_crisis "Greek government-debt crisis") and the decision of the government to proceed into [capital controls](/wiki/Capital_controls_in_Greece "Capital controls in Greece") during summer 2015. As a whole the economy of Athens and Greece was strongly affected, while data showed a change from long recession to growth of 1.4% from 2017 onwards.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-96)^{#cite_ref-96}

Tourism is also a leading contributor to the economy of the city, as one of Europe's top destinations for city-break tourism, and also the gateway for excursions to both the islands and other parts of the mainland. Greece attracted 26.5 million visitors in 2015, 30.1 million visitors in 2017, and over 33 million in 2018, making Greece one of the [most visited countries in Europe](/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings#Europe "World Tourism rankings") and the world, and contributing 18% to the country's GDP. Athens welcomed more than 5 million tourists in 2018, and 1.4 million were "city-breakers"; this was an increase by over a million city-breakers since 2013.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-97)^{#cite_ref-97}  

### Tourism {#Tourism}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Tourism")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Monastiraki_Square_and_the_Acropolis_in_Summer.jpg/220px-Monastiraki_Square_and_the_Acropolis_in_Summer.jpg)](/wiki/File:Monastiraki_Square_and_the_Acropolis_in_Summer.jpg) Monastiraki Square bustling with tourists during peak season

Athens has been a destination for travellers since antiquity. Over the 2000s, the city's infrastructure and social amenities have improved, in part because of its successful bid to stage the [2004 Olympic Games](/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics "2004 Summer Olympics").

The Greek Government, aided by the EU, has funded major infrastructure projects such as the state-of-the-art [Eleftherios Venizelos International Airport](/wiki/Athens_International_Airport "Athens International Airport"),^[\[97\]](#cite_note-98)^ the expansion of the [Athens Metro](/wiki/Athens_Metro "Athens Metro") system,^[\[54\]](#cite_note-EUfund-55)^ and the new [Attiki Odos](/wiki/Attiki_Odos "Attiki Odos") Motorway.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-EUfund-55)^{#cite_ref-EUfund_55-2}

In recent years, Athens has become more dynamic with the addition of numerous new bars and cafés and a growing presence of [street art](/wiki/Street_art "Street art") and [graffiti](/wiki/Graffiti "Graffiti"), enhancing its urban edge and adding more touristic options alongside the city's archaeological sites and museums.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-99)^{#cite_ref-99}
