Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Transport")\]  
Main article: [Public transport in Athens](/wiki/Public_transport_in_Athens "Public transport in Athens")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Public_transport_map_of_Athens.png/220px-Public_transport_map_of_Athens.png)](/wiki/File:Public_transport_map_of_Athens.png) Athens railways network (Metro, Suburban Railway and Tram)

Athens is the country's major transportation hub. The city has Greece's largest airport and its largest port; Piraeus, too, is the largest container transport port in the Mediterranean, and the largest passenger port in Europe.

Athens is a major national hub for Intercity ([Ktel](/wiki/KTEL_(Greece) "KTEL (Greece)")) and international buses, as well as for domestic and international rail transport. Public transport is serviced by a variety of transportation means, making up the country's largest mass transit system. [Transport for Athens](/wiki/Transport_for_Athens "Transport for Athens") operates a large bus and [trolleybus](/wiki/Trolleybus "Trolleybus") fleet, the city's [Metro](/wiki/Athens_Metro "Athens Metro"), a [Suburban Railway](/wiki/Athens_Suburban_Railway "Athens Suburban Railway") service^[\[99\]](#cite_note-100)^ and a [tram network](/wiki/Athens_Tram "Athens Tram"), connecting the southern suburbs to the city centre.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-101)^{#cite_ref-101}  

### Bus transport {#Bus_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Bus transport")\]

OSY ([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): ΟΣΥ) (Odikes Sygkoinonies S.A.), a subsidiary company of OASA (Athens urban transport organisation), is the main operator of buses and trolleybuses in Athens. As of 2017, its network consists of around 322 bus lines, spanning the Athens Metropolitan Area, and making up a fleet of 2,375 buses and trolleybuses. Of those 2,375, 619 buses run on [compressed natural gas](/wiki/Compressed_natural_gas "Compressed natural gas"), making up the largest fleet of natural gas-powered buses in Europe, and 354 are electric-powered (trolleybuses). All of the 354 trolleybuses are equipped to run on diesel in case of [power failure](/wiki/Power_outage "Power outage").^[\[101\]](#cite_note-102)^{#cite_ref-102}

International links are provided by a number of private companies. National and regional bus links are provided by [KTEL](/wiki/KTEL_(Greece) "KTEL (Greece)") from two InterCity Bus Terminals; [Kifissos Bus Terminal](/wiki/Athens_Peloponnese_Bus_Station "Athens Peloponnese Bus Station") A and [Liosion Bus Terminal](/wiki/Athens_Liosion_Bus_Station "Athens Liosion Bus Station") B, both located in the north-western part of the city. *Kifissos* provides connections towards [Peloponnese](/wiki/Peloponnese "Peloponnese"), North Greece, West Greece and some [Ionian Islands](/wiki/Ionian_Islands "Ionian Islands"), whereas *Liosion* is used for most of Central Greece. Both of these terminals will be replaced by a new Intercity Bus Terminal under construction in [Eleonas](/wiki/Elaionas "Elaionas") due to be completed by 2027.  

### Railways {#Railways}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Railways")\]  
Main articles: [Athens Metro](/wiki/Athens_Metro "Athens Metro"), [Proastiakos](/wiki/Proastiakos "Proastiakos"), and [Athens Tram](/wiki/Athens_Tram "Athens Tram")

Athens is the hub of the [country's national railway system](/wiki/Hellenic_Railways_Organisation "Hellenic Railways Organisation") (OSE), connecting the capital with major cities across Greece and abroad ([Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul"), [Sofia](/wiki/Sofia "Sofia"), Belgrade and [Bucharest](/wiki/Bucharest "Bucharest")).
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Athens_Larissa_Station_09.jpg/220px-Athens_Larissa_Station_09.jpg)](/wiki/File:Athens_Larissa_Station_09.jpg) Suburban rail ([Proastiakos](/wiki/Proastiakos "Proastiakos"))

The [Athens Suburban Railway](/wiki/Athens_Suburban_Railway "Athens Suburban Railway"), referred to as the *[Proastiakos](/wiki/Proastiakos "Proastiakos")* , connects Athens International Airport to the city of [Kiato](/wiki/Kiato "Kiato"), 106 km (66 mi)^[\[102\]](#cite_note-proastiakos-103)^ west of Athens, via Larissa station, the city's central rail station and the port of Piraeus. The length of Athens's commuter rail network extends to 120 km (75 mi),^[\[102\]](#cite_note-proastiakos-103)^ and is expected to stretch to 281 km (175 mi) by 2010.^[\[102\]](#cite_note-proastiakos-103)^{#cite_ref-proastiakos_103-2}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/20140622-Anthoupoli-62D304_%287872%29.jpg/220px-20140622-Anthoupoli-62D304_%287872%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:20140622-Anthoupoli-62D304_(7872).jpg) [Athens Metro](/wiki/Athens_Metro "Athens Metro") train (3rd generation stock)

The [Athens Metro](/wiki/Athens_Metro "Athens Metro") is operated by STASY S.A. ([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): ΣΤΑΣΥ) (Statheres Sygkoinonies S.A.), a subsidiary company of OASA (Athens urban transport organisation), which provides public transport throughout the Athens Urban Area. While its main purpose is transport, it also houses Greek artifacts found during the construction of the system.^[\[103\]](#cite_note-104)^ The Athens Metro runs three metro lines, namely [Line 1 (Green Line)](/wiki/Athens_Metro_Line_1 "Athens Metro Line 1"), [Line 2 (Red Line)](/wiki/Athens_Metro_Line_2 "Athens Metro Line 2") and [Line 3 (Blue Line)](/wiki/Athens_Metro_Line_3 "Athens Metro Line 3") lines, of which the first was constructed in 1869, and the other two largely during the 1990s, with the initial new sections opened in January 2000. Line 1 mostly runs at ground level and the other two (Line 2 \& 3) routes run entirely underground. A fleet of 42 trains, using 252 carriages, operates on the network,^[\[104\]](#cite_note-xyz-105)^ with a daily occupancy of 1,353,000 passengers.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-106)^{#cite_ref-106}

*Line 1* (Green Line) serves 24 stations, and is the oldest line of the Athens metro network. It runs from [Piraeus](/wiki/Piraeus "Piraeus") station to [Kifissia](/wiki/Kifissia "Kifissia") station and covers a distance of 25.6 km (15.9 mi). There are transfer connections with the Blue Line 3 at [Monastiraki](/wiki/Monastiraki "Monastiraki") station and with the Red Line 2 at [Omonia](/wiki/Omonoia_Square "Omonoia Square") and [Attiki](/wiki/Attiki "Attiki") stations. *Line 2* (Red Line) runs from [Anthoupoli](/wiki/Anthoupoli_metro_station "Anthoupoli metro station") station to [Elliniko](/wiki/Elliniko_metro_station "Elliniko metro station") station and covers a distance of 17.5 km (10.9 mi).^[\[104\]](#cite_note-xyz-105)^ The line connects the western suburbs of Athens with the southeast suburbs, passing through the center of Athens. The Red Line has transfer connections with the Green Line 1 at [Attiki](/wiki/Attiki_metro_station "Attiki metro station") and [Omonia](/wiki/Omonia_metro_station "Omonia metro station") stations. There are also transfer connections with the Blue Line 3 at [Syntagma](/wiki/Syntagma_Square "Syntagma Square") [station](/wiki/Syntagma_metro_station "Syntagma metro station") and with the tram at [Syntagma](/wiki/Syntagma_Square "Syntagma Square"), [Syngrou Fix](/wiki/Syngrou%E2%80%93Fix_station "Syngrou–Fix station") and [Neos Kosmos](/wiki/Neos_Kosmos_station "Neos Kosmos station") stations. *Line 3* (Blue Line) runs from [Dimotiko Theatro](/wiki/Dimotiko_Theatro_metro_station "Dimotiko Theatro metro station") station, through the central [Monastiraki](/wiki/Monastiraki "Monastiraki") and [Syntagma](/wiki/Syntagma_metro_station "Syntagma metro station") stations to [Doukissis Plakentias](/wiki/Doukissis_Plakentias_station "Doukissis Plakentias station") avenue in the northeastern suburb of [Halandri](/wiki/Chalandri "Chalandri").^[\[104\]](#cite_note-xyz-105)^ It then ascends to ground level and continues to [Athens International Airport Eleftherios Venizelos](/wiki/Athens_International_Airport "Athens International Airport") using the suburban railway infrastructure, extending its total length to 39 km (24 mi).^[\[104\]](#cite_note-xyz-105)^ The spring 2007 extension from Monastiraki westwards to [Egaleo](/wiki/Egaleo "Egaleo") connected some of the main [night life](/wiki/Nightlife "Nightlife") hubs of the city, namely those of Gazi ([Kerameikos](/wiki/Kerameikos_metro_station "Kerameikos metro station") station) with Psirri ([Monastiraki](/wiki/Monastiraki_metro_station "Monastiraki metro station") station) and the city centre ([Syntagma station](/wiki/Syntagma_station "Syntagma station")).The new stations [Maniatika](/wiki/Maniatika_metro_station "Maniatika metro station"), [Piraeus](/wiki/Piraeus_station "Piraeus station") and [Dimotiko Theatro](/wiki/Dimotiko_Theatro_metro_station "Dimotiko Theatro metro station"), were completed on 10 October 2022,^[\[106\]](#cite_note-Attiko_Metro-107)^^[\[107\]](#cite_note-Athens_Greece_Guide-108)^ connecting the biggest port of Greece, the Port of Piraeus, with Athens International Airport, the biggest airport of Greece.{#cite_ref-Athens_Greece_Guide_108-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Attica_06-13_Athens_26_Tram.jpg/220px-Attica_06-13_Athens_26_Tram.jpg)](/wiki/File:Attica_06-13_Athens_26_Tram.jpg) Vehicle of the [Athens Tram](/wiki/Athens_Tram "Athens Tram")

The [Athens Tram](/wiki/Athens_Tram "Athens Tram") is operated by STASY S.A. (Statheres Sygkoinonies S.A.), a subsidiary company of [Transport for Athens](/wiki/Transport_for_Athens "Transport for Athens") (OASA). It has a fleet of 35 [Sirio](/wiki/Sirio "Sirio") type vehicles^[\[108\]](#cite_note-athenstram-109)^ and 25 [Alstom Citadis](/wiki/Alstom_Citadis "Alstom Citadis") type vehicles^[\[109\]](#cite_note-110)^ which serve 48 stations,^[\[108\]](#cite_note-athenstram-109)^ employ 345 people with an average daily occupancy of 65,000 passengers.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-athenstram-109)^ The tram network spans a total length of 27 km (17 mi) and covers ten Athenian suburbs.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-athenstram-109)^ The network runs from [Syntagma Square](/wiki/Syntagma_Square "Syntagma Square") to the southwestern suburb of [Palaio Faliro](/wiki/Palaio_Faliro "Palaio Faliro"), where the line splits in two branches; the first runs along the Athens coastline toward the southern suburb of [Voula](/wiki/Voula "Voula"), while the other heads toward Piraeus. The network covers the majority of the Athens coastline.^[\[110\]](#cite_note-EF-111)^{#cite_ref-EF_111-0}  

### Athens International Airport {#Athens_International_Airport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Athens International Airport")\]  
Main article: [Athens International Airport](/wiki/Athens_International_Airport "Athens International Airport")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Greece-0028_%282215861772%29.jpg/220px-Greece-0028_%282215861772%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Greece-0028_(2215861772).jpg) [Athens International Airport](/wiki/Athens_International_Airport "Athens International Airport")

Athens is served by the [Athens International Airport](/wiki/Athens_International_Airport "Athens International Airport") (ATH), located near the town of [Spata](/wiki/Spata "Spata"), in the eastern Messoghia plain, some 35 km (22 mi) east of center of Athens.^[\[111\]](#cite_note-aia-112)^ The airport, awarded the "European Airport of the Year 2004" Award,^[\[112\]](#cite_note-pro-113)^ is intended as an expandable hub for air travel in [southeastern Europe](/wiki/Balkans "Balkans") and was constructed in 51 months, costing 2.2 billion euros. It employs a staff of 14,000.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-pro-113)^{#cite_ref-pro_113-1}  

### Ferry {#Ferry}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Ferry")\]

The [Port of Piraeus](/wiki/Port_of_Piraeus "Port of Piraeus") is the largest port in Greece and one of the largest in Europe. [Rafina](/wiki/Rafina "Rafina") and [Lavrio](/wiki/Lavrio "Lavrio") act as alternative ports of Athens, connects the city with numerous [Greek islands](/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Greece "List of islands of Greece") of the [Aegean Sea](/wiki/Aegean_Sea "Aegean Sea"), [Evia](/wiki/Euboea "Euboea") while also serving the cruise ships that arrive.  

### Motorways {#Motorways}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Motorways")\]  
Further information: [National Roads and Motorways in Greece](/wiki/National_Roads_and_Motorways_in_Greece "National Roads and Motorways in Greece")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Athens-Kiffisia-aerial.jpg/220px-Athens-Kiffisia-aerial.jpg)](/wiki/File:Athens-Kiffisia-aerial.jpg) Aerial view of an [A6](/wiki/A6_motorway_(Greece) "A6 motorway (Greece)") interchange north of Athens

Two main motorways of Greece begin in Athens, namely the [A1](/wiki/A1_motorway_(Greece) "A1 motorway (Greece)")/[E75](/wiki/European_route_E75 "European route E75"), heading north towards Greece's second largest city, [Thessaloniki](/wiki/Thessaloniki "Thessaloniki"); and the border crossing of Evzones and the [A8](/wiki/A8_motorway_(Greece) "A8 motorway (Greece)")/[E94](/wiki/European_route_E94 "European route E94") heading west, towards Greece's third largest city, [Patras](/wiki/Patras "Patras"), which incorporated the [GR-8A](/wiki/Greek_National_Road_8A "Greek National Road 8A"). Before their completion much of the road traffic used the [GR-1](/wiki/Greek_National_Road_1 "Greek National Road 1") and the [GR-8](/wiki/Greek_National_Road_8 "Greek National Road 8").

Athens' Metropolitan Area is served by the [Attiki Odos](/wiki/Attiki_Odos "Attiki Odos") toll motorway network: its main section, the [A6](/wiki/A6_motorway_(Greece) "A6 motorway (Greece)"), extends from the western industrial suburb of [Elefsina](/wiki/Eleusina "Eleusina") to [Athens International Airport](/wiki/Athens_International_Airport "Athens International Airport"); while two beltways, namely the Aigaleo Beltway ([A65](/wiki/A65_motorway_(Greece) "A65 motorway (Greece)")) and the Hymettus Beltway ([A62](/wiki/A62_motorway_(Greece) "A62 motorway (Greece)")) serve parts of western and eastern Athens respectively. The span of the Attiki Odos in all its length is 65 km (40 mi),^[\[113\]](#cite_note-114)^ making it the largest metropolitan motorway network in all of Greece.{#cite_ref-114}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Education")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/%CE%91%CE%BA%CE%B1%CE%B4%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%AF%CE%B1_%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CF%8E%CE%BD_1178.jpg/220px-%CE%91%CE%BA%CE%B1%CE%B4%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%AF%CE%B1_%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CF%8E%CE%BD_1178.jpg)](/wiki/File:%CE%91%CE%BA%CE%B1%CE%B4%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%AF%CE%B1_%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CF%8E%CE%BD_1178.jpg) Facade of the [Academy of Athens](/wiki/Academy_of_Athens_(modern) "Academy of Athens (modern)") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Universit%C3%A4t_von_Athen.jpg/220px-Universit%C3%A4t_von_Athen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Universit%C3%A4t_von_Athen.jpg) [University of Athens](/wiki/National_and_Kapodistrian_University_of_Athens "National and Kapodistrian University of Athens") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Griechische_Nationalbibliothek.jpg/220px-Griechische_Nationalbibliothek.jpg)](/wiki/File:Griechische_Nationalbibliothek.jpg) The [National Library of Greece](/wiki/National_Library_of_Greece "National Library of Greece").

Located on [Panepistimiou Street](/wiki/Panepistimiou_Street "Panepistimiou Street"), the old campus of the [University of Athens](/wiki/National_and_Kapodistrian_University_of_Athens "National and Kapodistrian University of Athens"), the [National Library](/wiki/National_Library_of_Greece "National Library of Greece"), and the [Athens Academy](/wiki/Academy_of_Athens_(modern) "Academy of Athens (modern)") form the "Athens Trilogy" built in the mid-19th century. The largest and oldest university in Athens is the National and Kapodistrian University of Athens. Most of the functions of NKUA along National Technical University of Athens have been transferred to a campus in the eastern suburb of [Zografou](/wiki/Zografou "Zografou"). The [National Technical University of Athens](/wiki/National_Technical_University_of_Athens "National Technical University of Athens") old campus is located on Patision Street.

The [University of West Attica](/wiki/University_of_West_Attica "University of West Attica") is the second largest university in Athens. The seat of the university is located in the western area of Athens, where the philosophers of Ancient Athens delivered lectures. All the activities of UNIWA are carried out in the modern infrastructure of the three University Campuses within the metropolitan region of Athens (Egaleo Park, Ancient Olive Groove and Athens), which offer modern teaching and research spaces, entertainment and support facilities for all students. Other universities that lie within Athens are the [Athens University of Economics and Business](/wiki/Athens_University_of_Economics_and_Business "Athens University of Economics and Business"), the [Panteion University](/wiki/Panteion_University "Panteion University"), the [Agricultural University of Athens](/wiki/Agricultural_University_of_Athens "Agricultural University of Athens") and the [University of Piraeus](/wiki/University_of_Piraeus "University of Piraeus").

There are overall ten state-supported Institutions of Higher (or Tertiary) education located in the Athens Urban Area, these are by chronological order: [Athens School of Fine Arts](/wiki/Athens_School_of_Fine_Arts "Athens School of Fine Arts") (1837), [National Technical University of Athens](/wiki/National_Technical_University_of_Athens "National Technical University of Athens") (1837), [National and Kapodistrian University of Athens](/wiki/National_and_Kapodistrian_University_of_Athens "National and Kapodistrian University of Athens") (1837), [Agricultural University of Athens](/wiki/Agricultural_University_of_Athens "Agricultural University of Athens") (1920), [Athens University of Economics and Business](/wiki/Athens_University_of_Economics_and_Business "Athens University of Economics and Business") (1920), [Panteion University of Social and Political Sciences](/wiki/Panteion_University "Panteion University") (1927), [University of Piraeus](/wiki/University_of_Piraeus "University of Piraeus") (1938), [Harokopio University of Athens](/wiki/Harokopio_University "Harokopio University") (1990), [School of Pedagogical and Technological Education](/wiki/School_of_Pedagogical_and_Technological_Education "School of Pedagogical and Technological Education") (2002), [University of West Attica](/wiki/University_of_West_Attica "University of West Attica") (2018). There are also several other private *colleges* , as they called formally in Greece, as the establishment of private universities is prohibited by the constitution. Many of them are accredited by a foreign state or university such as the [American College of Greece](/wiki/American_College_of_Greece "American College of Greece") and the [Athens Campus](/wiki/University_of_Indianapolis_%E2%80%93_Athens_Campus "University of Indianapolis – Athens Campus") of the [University of Indianapolis](/wiki/University_of_Indianapolis "University of Indianapolis").^[\[114\]](#cite_note-115)^{#cite_ref-115}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Culture")\]  
Main article: [Culture of Greece](/wiki/Culture_of_Greece "Culture of Greece")  

### Archaeological hub and museums {#Archaeological_hub_and_museums}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Archaeological hub and museums")\]  
Further information: [List of museums in Greece](/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Greece "List of museums in Greece")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Arch%C3%A4ologisches_Nationalmuseum_Athen.jpg/220px-Arch%C3%A4ologisches_Nationalmuseum_Athen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Arch%C3%A4ologisches_Nationalmuseum_Athen.jpg) The [National Archaeological Museum](/wiki/National_Archaeological_Museum,_Athens "National Archaeological Museum, Athens") in central Athens [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/3b/The_Acropolis_Museum_as_seen_from_the_top_of_the_Acropolis_hill.jpg/220px-The_Acropolis_Museum_as_seen_from_the_top_of_the_Acropolis_hill.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Acropolis_Museum_as_seen_from_the_top_of_the_Acropolis_hill.jpg) The [Acropolis Museum](/wiki/Acropolis_Museum "Acropolis Museum") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/The_Stoa_of_Attalus_on_February_26%2C_2022.jpg/220px-The_Stoa_of_Attalus_on_February_26%2C_2022.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Stoa_of_Attalus_on_February_26,_2022.jpg) [Museum of the Ancient Agora](/wiki/Museum_of_the_Ancient_Agora "Museum of the Ancient Agora") in the [Stoa of Attalos](/wiki/Stoa_of_Attalos "Stoa of Attalos")

The city is a world centre of [archaeological research](/wiki/Archaeology "Archaeology"). Alongside national academic institutions, such as the [Athens University](/wiki/National_and_Kapodistrian_University_of_Athens "National and Kapodistrian University of Athens") and the [Archaeological Society](/wiki/Archaeological_Society_of_Athens "Archaeological Society of Athens"), it is home to multiple archaeological museums, taking in the [National Archaeological Museum](/wiki/National_Archaeological_Museum,_Athens "National Archaeological Museum, Athens"), the [Cycladic Museum](/wiki/Goulandris_Museum_of_Cycladic_Art "Goulandris Museum of Cycladic Art"), the [Epigraphic](/wiki/Epigraphy "Epigraphy") Museum, the [Byzantine \& Christian Museum](/wiki/Byzantine_%26_Christian_Museum "Byzantine & Christian Museum"), as well as museums at the ancient Agora, [Acropolis](/wiki/Acropolis_Museum "Acropolis Museum"), [Kerameikos](/wiki/Kerameikos "Kerameikos"), and the [Kerameikos Archaeological Museum](/wiki/Kerameikos_Archaeological_Museum "Kerameikos Archaeological Museum"). The city is also the setting for the [Demokritos](/wiki/Democritus "Democritus") laboratory for [Archaeometry](/wiki/Archaeological_science "Archaeological science"), alongside regional and national archaeological authorities forming part of the [Greek Department of Culture](/wiki/Minister_for_Culture_(Greece) "Minister for Culture (Greece)").

Athens hosts 17 [Foreign Archaeological Institutes](/wiki/List_of_Foreign_Archaeological_Institutes_in_Greece "List of Foreign Archaeological Institutes in Greece") which promote and facilitate research by scholars from their home countries. As a result, Athens has more than a dozen archaeological libraries and three specialized archaeological laboratories, and is the venue of several hundred specialized lectures, conferences and seminars, as well as dozens of archaeological exhibitions each year. At any given time, hundreds of international scholars and researchers in all disciplines of archaeology are to be found in the city.

Athens' most important museums include:

* the [National Archaeological Museum](/wiki/National_Archaeological_Museum,_Athens "National Archaeological Museum, Athens"), the largest archaeological museum in the country, and one of the most important internationally, as it contains a vast collection of antiquities. Its artefacts cover a period of more than 5,000 years, from late [Neolithic](/wiki/Neolithic "Neolithic") Age to [Roman Greece](/wiki/Roman_Greece "Roman Greece");
* the [Benaki Museum](/wiki/Benaki_Museum "Benaki Museum") with its several branches for each of its collections including ancient, Byzantine, Ottoman-era, Chinese art and beyond;
* the [Byzantine and Christian Museum](/wiki/Byzantine_%26_Christian_Museum "Byzantine & Christian Museum"), one of the most important museums of [Byzantine art](/wiki/Byzantine_art "Byzantine art");
* the [National Art Gallery](/wiki/National_Gallery_(Athens) "National Gallery (Athens)"), the nation's eponymous leading gallery, which reopened in 2021 after renovation;
* the [National Museum of Contemporary Art](/wiki/Athens_National_Museum_of_Contemporary_Art "Athens National Museum of Contemporary Art"), which opened in 2000 in a former brewery building;
* the [Numismatic Museum](/wiki/Numismatic_Museum_of_Athens "Numismatic Museum of Athens"), housing a major collection of ancient and modern coins;
* the [Museum of Cycladic Art](/wiki/Goulandris_Museum_of_Cycladic_Art "Goulandris Museum of Cycladic Art"), home to an extensive collection of [Cycladic art](/wiki/Cycladic_art "Cycladic art"), including its famous figurines of white marble;
* the [New Acropolis Museum](/wiki/Acropolis_Museum "Acropolis Museum"), opened in 2009, and replacing the old museum on the Acropolis. The new museum has proved considerably popular; almost one million people visited during the summer period June--October 2009 alone. A number of smaller and privately owned museums focused on Greek culture and arts are also to be found.
* the [Kerameikos Archaeological Museum](/wiki/Kerameikos_Archaeological_Museum "Kerameikos Archaeological Museum"), a museum which displays artifacts from the burial site of Kerameikos. Much of the pottery and other artifacts relate to Athenian attitudes towards death and the afterlife, throughout many ages.
* the [Jewish Museum of Greece](/wiki/Jewish_Museum_of_Greece "Jewish Museum of Greece"), a museum which describes the history and culture of [the Greek Jewish community](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Greece "History of the Jews in Greece").

### Architecture {#Architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Architecture")\]  
See also: [Modern architecture in Athens](/wiki/Modern_architecture_in_Athens "Modern architecture in Athens")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Attica_06-13_Athens_27_Zappeion.jpg/220px-Attica_06-13_Athens_27_Zappeion.jpg)](/wiki/File:Attica_06-13_Athens_27_Zappeion.jpg) The [Zappeion](/wiki/Zappeion "Zappeion") Hall [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/%CE%9C%CE%B7%CF%84%CF%81%CF%8C%CF%80%CE%BF%CE%BB%CE%B7_%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CF%8E%CE%BD_3321.jpg/220px-%CE%9C%CE%B7%CF%84%CF%81%CF%8C%CF%80%CE%BF%CE%BB%CE%B7_%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CF%8E%CE%BD_3321.jpg)](/wiki/File:%CE%9C%CE%B7%CF%84%CF%81%CF%8C%CF%80%CE%BF%CE%BB%CE%B7_%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CF%8E%CE%BD_3321.jpg) The [Cathedral of Athens](/wiki/Metropolitan_Cathedral_of_Athens "Metropolitan Cathedral of Athens") (Athens Metropolis)

Athens incorporates [architectural styles](/wiki/Architectural_style "Architectural style") ranging from [Greco-Roman](/wiki/Greek_Revival_architecture "Greek Revival architecture") and [Neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") to Modern. They are often to be found in the same areas, as Athens is not marked by a uniformity of architectural style. A visitor will quickly notice the absence of tall buildings: Athens has very strict [height restriction laws](/wiki/Height_restriction_laws "Height restriction laws") in order to ensure the Acropolis Hill is visible throughout the city. Despite the variety in styles, there is evidence of continuity in elements of the architectural environment throughout the city's history.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-116)^{#cite_ref-116}

For the greatest part of the 19th century Neoclassicism dominated Athens, as well as some deviations from it such as [Eclecticism](/wiki/Eclecticism "Eclecticism"), especially in the early 20th century. Thus, the [Old Royal Palace](/wiki/Old_Royal_Palace "Old Royal Palace") was the first important public building to be built, between 1836 and 1843. Later in the mid and late 19th century, [Theophil Freiherr von Hansen](/wiki/Baron_Theophil_von_Hansen "Baron Theophil von Hansen") and [Ernst Ziller](/wiki/Ernst_Ziller "Ernst Ziller") took part in the construction of many neoclassical buildings such as the [Athens Academy](/wiki/Academy_of_Athens_(modern) "Academy of Athens (modern)") and the [Zappeion](/wiki/Zappeion "Zappeion") Hall. Ziller also designed many private mansions in the centre of Athens which gradually became public, usually through donations, such as [Schliemann](/wiki/Heinrich_Schliemann "Heinrich Schliemann")'s [Iliou Melathron](/wiki/Iliou_Melathron "Iliou Melathron").

Beginning in the 1920s, [modern architecture](/wiki/Modern_architecture "Modern architecture") including [Bauhaus](/wiki/Bauhaus "Bauhaus") and [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco") began to exert an influence on almost all Greek architects, and buildings both public and private were constructed in accordance with these styles. Localities with a great number of such buildings include [Kolonaki](/wiki/Kolonaki "Kolonaki"), and some areas of the centre of the city; neighbourhoods developed in this period include [Kypseli](/wiki/Kypseli,_Athens "Kypseli, Athens").^[\[116\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}

In the 1950s and 1960s during the extension and development of Athens, other modern movements such as the [International style](/wiki/International_Style_(architecture) "International Style (architecture)") played an important role. The centre of Athens was largely rebuilt, leading to the demolition of a number of neoclassical buildings. The architects of this era employed materials such as glass, marble and aluminium, and many blended modern and classical elements.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-118)^ After World War II, internationally known architects to have designed and built in the city included [Walter Gropius](/wiki/Walter_Gropius "Walter Gropius"), with his design for the US Embassy, and, among others, [Eero Saarinen](/wiki/Eero_Saarinen "Eero Saarinen"), in his postwar design for the east terminal of the [Ellinikon Airport](/wiki/Ellinikon_International_Airport "Ellinikon International Airport").{#cite_ref-118}  

### Urban sculpture {#Urban_sculpture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Urban sculpture")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/The_Old_Parliament_House_-_National_Historical_Museum_-_on_March_1%2C_2019.jpg/220px-The_Old_Parliament_House_-_National_Historical_Museum_-_on_March_1%2C_2019.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Old_Parliament_House_-_National_Historical_Museum_-_on_March_1,_2019.jpg) The [Old Parliament House](/wiki/Old_Parliament_House,_Athens "Old Parliament House, Athens"), now home to the National History Museum. View from [Stadiou Street](/wiki/Stadiou_Street "Stadiou Street").

Across the city numerous statues or busts are to be found. Apart from the neoclassicals by [Leonidas Drosis](/wiki/Leonidas_Drosis "Leonidas Drosis") at the Academy of Athens (Plato, Socrates, Apollo and Athena), others in notable categories include the statue of [Theseus](/wiki/Theseus "Theseus") by [Georgios Fytalis](/w/index.php?title=Georgios_Fytalis&action=edit&redlink=1 "Georgios Fytalis (page does not exist)") at Thiseion; depictions of philhellenes such as [Lord Byron](/wiki/Lord_Byron "Lord Byron"), [George Canning](/wiki/George_Canning "George Canning"), and [William Gladstone](/wiki/William_Ewart_Gladstone "William Ewart Gladstone"); the equestrian statue of [Theodoros Kolokotronis](/wiki/Theodoros_Kolokotronis "Theodoros Kolokotronis") by [Lazaros Sochos](/wiki/Lazaros_Sochos "Lazaros Sochos") in front of the Old Parliament; statues of [Ioannis Kapodistrias](/wiki/Ioannis_Kapodistrias "Ioannis Kapodistrias"), [Rigas Feraios](/wiki/Rigas_Feraios "Rigas Feraios") and [Adamantios Korais](/wiki/Adamantios_Korais "Adamantios Korais") at the university; of [Evangelos Zappas](/wiki/Evangelos_Zappas "Evangelos Zappas") and [Konstantinos Zappas](/wiki/Konstantinos_Zappas "Konstantinos Zappas") at the Zappeion; [Ioannis Varvakis](/wiki/Ioannis_Varvakis "Ioannis Varvakis") at the National Garden; the" Woodbreaker" by [Dimitrios Filippotis](/w/index.php?title=Dimitrios_Filippotis&action=edit&redlink=1 "Dimitrios Filippotis (page does not exist)"); the equestrian statue of [Alexandros Papagos](/wiki/Alexandros_Papagos "Alexandros Papagos") in the Papagou district; and various busts of fighters of Greek independence at the [Pedion tou Areos](/wiki/Pedion_tou_Areos "Pedion tou Areos"). A significant landmark is also the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Syntagma.  

### Entertainment and performing arts {#Entertainment_and_performing_arts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Entertainment and performing arts")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/%CE%95%CE%B8%CE%BD%CE%B9%CE%BA%CF%8C_%CE%98%CE%AD%CE%B1%CF%84%CF%81%CE%BF_%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CF%8E%CE%BD_9854.jpg/220px-%CE%95%CE%B8%CE%BD%CE%B9%CE%BA%CF%8C_%CE%98%CE%AD%CE%B1%CF%84%CF%81%CE%BF_%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CF%8E%CE%BD_9854.jpg)](/wiki/File:%CE%95%CE%B8%CE%BD%CE%B9%CE%BA%CF%8C_%CE%98%CE%AD%CE%B1%CF%84%CF%81%CE%BF_%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CF%8E%CE%BD_9854.jpg) The [National Theatre of Greece](/wiki/National_Theatre_of_Greece "National Theatre of Greece"), near [Omonoia Square](/wiki/Omonoia_Square "Omonoia Square")

Athens is home to 148 theatrical stages, more than any other city in the world, including the ancient [Odeon of Herodes Atticus](/wiki/Odeon_of_Herodes_Atticus "Odeon of Herodes Atticus"), home to the [Athens Festival](/wiki/Athens_Festival "Athens Festival"), which runs from May to October each year.^[\[118\]](#cite_note-119)^^[\[119\]](#cite_note-120)^ In addition to a large number of multiplexes, Athens plays host to open air garden cinemas. The city also supports music venues, including the [Athens Concert Hall](/wiki/Athens_Concert_Hall "Athens Concert Hall") (*Megaro Moussikis* ), which attracts world class artists.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-121)^ The Athens [Planetarium](/wiki/Planetarium "Planetarium"),^[\[121\]](#cite_note-122)^ located in [Andrea Syngrou Avenue](/wiki/Andrea_Syngrou_Avenue "Andrea Syngrou Avenue"), in [Palaio Faliro](/wiki/Palaio_Faliro "Palaio Faliro")^[\[122\]](#cite_note-123)^ is one of the largest and best equipped digital planetaria in the world.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-124)^ The [Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center](/wiki/Stavros_Niarchos_Foundation_Cultural_Center "Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center"), inaugurated in 2016, will house the [National Library of Greece](/wiki/National_Library_of_Greece "National Library of Greece") and the [Greek National Opera](/wiki/Greek_National_Opera "Greek National Opera").^[\[124\]](#cite_note-125)^ In 2018 Athens was designated as the [World Book Capital](/wiki/World_Book_Capital "World Book Capital") by [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO").^[\[125\]](#cite_note-126)^{#cite_ref-126}

Restaurants, tavernas and bars can be found in the entertainment hubs in [Plaka](/wiki/Plaka "Plaka") and the [Trigono](/wiki/Monastiraki "Monastiraki") areas of the historic centre, the inner suburbs of [Gazi](/wiki/Gazi,_Athens "Gazi, Athens") and [Psyrri](/wiki/Psyri "Psyri") are especially busy with nightclubs and bars, while [Kolonaki](/wiki/Kolonaki "Kolonaki"), [Exarchia](/wiki/Exarcheia "Exarcheia"), [Kypseli](/wiki/Kypseli,_Athens "Kypseli, Athens"), [Metaxourgeio](/wiki/Metaxourgeio "Metaxourgeio"), [Koukaki](/wiki/Koukaki "Koukaki") and [Pangrati](/wiki/Pangrati "Pangrati") offer more of a cafe and restaurant scene. The coastal suburbs of [Microlimano](/wiki/Piraeus "Piraeus"), [Alimos](/wiki/Alimos "Alimos") and [Glyfada](/wiki/Glyfada "Glyfada") include many tavernas, beach bars and busy summer clubs.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Stavros_Niarchos_Foundation_Cultural_Center_-_52035330487.jpg/220px-Stavros_Niarchos_Foundation_Cultural_Center_-_52035330487.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stavros_Niarchos_Foundation_Cultural_Center_-_52035330487.jpg) [The Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Centre](/wiki/Stavros_Niarchos_Foundation_Cultural_Center "Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center"), home of the [Greek National Opera](/wiki/Greek_National_Opera "Greek National Opera") and the new [National Library](/wiki/National_Library_of_Greece "National Library of Greece")

The most successful songs during the period 1870--1930 were the Athenian serenades (Αθηναϊκές καντάδες), based on the [Heptanesean](/wiki/Heptanese "Heptanese") [kantádhes](/wiki/Greek_folk_music#Ionian_Islands "Greek folk music") (καντάδες '[serenades](/wiki/Serenade "Serenade")'; sing.: καντάδα) and the songs performed on stage (επιθεωρησιακά τραγούδια 'theatrical revue songs') in [revues](/wiki/Revues "Revues"), [musical comedies](/wiki/Musical_theatre "Musical theatre"), [operettas](/wiki/Operettas "Operettas") and [nocturnes](/wiki/Nocturnes "Nocturnes") that were dominating Athens' theatre scene.

In 1922, following the [Greek-Turkish war](/wiki/Greco-Turkish_War_(1919%E2%80%931922) "Greco-Turkish War (1919–1922)"), [Greek genocide](/wiki/Greek_genocide "Greek genocide") and later [population exchange](/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_and_Turkey "Population exchange between Greece and Turkey") suffered by the Greek population of Asia Minor, many ethnic Greeks fled to Athens. They settled in poor neighbourhoods and brought with them [Rebetiko](/wiki/Rebetiko "Rebetiko") music, making it also popular in Greece, and which later became the base for the [Laïko](/wiki/La%C3%AFko "Laïko") music. Other forms of song popular today in Greece are elafrolaika, entechno, dimotika, and skyladika.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-Tales_of_Orpheus-127)^ Greece's most notable, and internationally famous, composers of Greek song, mainly of the entechno form, are [Manos Hadjidakis](/wiki/Manos_Hadjidakis "Manos Hadjidakis") and [Mikis Theodorakis](/wiki/Mikis_Theodorakis "Mikis Theodorakis"). Both composers have achieved fame abroad for their composition of film scores.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-Tales_of_Orpheus-127)^{#cite_ref-Tales_of_Orpheus_127-1}

The renowned American-born Greek soprano [Maria Callas](/wiki/Maria_Callas "Maria Callas") spent her teenage years in Athens, where she settled in 1937.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-128)^^[\[128\]](#cite_note-129)^ Her professional opera career started in 1940 in Athens, with the [Greek National Opera](/wiki/Greek_National_Opera "Greek National Opera").^[\[129\]](#cite_note-130)^ In 2018, the city's municipal Olympia Theatre was renamed to "[Olympia City Music Theatre 'Maria Callas'](/wiki/Olympia_City_Music_Theatre_%22Maria_Callas%22 "Olympia City Music Theatre \"Maria Callas\"")"^[\[130\]](#cite_note-131)^^[\[131\]](#cite_note-132)^ and in 2023, the Municipality inaugurated the [Maria Callas Museum](/wiki/Maria_Callas_Museum "Maria Callas Museum"), housing it in a [neoclassical building](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") on 44 Mitropoleos street.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-133)^{#cite_ref-133}  

### Sports {#Sports}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Athens&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Sports")\]  
See also: [List of sports clubs in Athens Municipality](/wiki/List_of_sports_clubs_in_Athens_Municipality "List of sports clubs in Athens Municipality")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/The_Panathenaic_Stadium_on_April_22%2C_2021.jpg/220px-The_Panathenaic_Stadium_on_April_22%2C_2021.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Panathenaic_Stadium_on_April_22,_2021.jpg) The Panathenaic Stadium of Athens ([Kallimarmaron](/wiki/Panathenaic_Stadium "Panathenaic Stadium")) dates back to the fourth century BC and has hosted the [first modern Olympic Games](/wiki/1896_Summer_Olympics "1896 Summer Olympics") in 1896. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Panathinaikos_-_Sparta_Prague_DSC00055.JPG/220px-Panathinaikos_-_Sparta_Prague_DSC00055.JPG)](/wiki/File:Panathinaikos_-_Sparta_Prague_DSC00055.JPG) [Panathinaikos FC](/wiki/Panathinaikos_FC "Panathinaikos FC") vs [Sparta Prague](/wiki/Sparta_Prague "Sparta Prague") in the [Athens Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Athens_Olympic_Stadium "Athens Olympic Stadium"), 2008

Athens has a long tradition in sports and sporting events, serving as home to the most important clubs in [Greek sport](/wiki/Sport_in_Greece "Sport in Greece") and housing a large number of sports facilities. The city has also been host to sports events of international importance.

Athens has hosted the [Summer Olympic Games](/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games "Summer Olympic Games") twice, in [1896](/wiki/1896_Summer_Olympics "1896 Summer Olympics") and [2004](/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics "2004 Summer Olympics"). The 2004 Summer Olympics required the development of the [Athens Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Olympic_Stadium_(Athens) "Olympic Stadium (Athens)"), which has since gained a reputation as one of the most beautiful stadiums in the world, and one of its most interesting modern monuments.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-134)^ The biggest stadium in the country, it hosted two finals of the [UEFA Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League"), in [1994](/wiki/1994_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "1994 UEFA Champions League Final") and [2007](/wiki/2007_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2007 UEFA Champions League Final"). Other major stadiums are the [Karaiskakis Stadium](/wiki/Karaiskakis_Stadium "Karaiskakis Stadium") located in the nearby city of [Piraeus](/wiki/Piraeus "Piraeus"), a sports and entertainment complex, host of the [1971 UEFA Cup Winners' Cup Final](/wiki/1971_European_Cup_Winners%27_Cup_Final "1971 European Cup Winners' Cup Final"), and [Agia Sophia Stadium](/wiki/Agia_Sophia_Stadium "Agia Sophia Stadium") located in [Nea Filadelfeia](/wiki/Nea_Filadelfeia "Nea Filadelfeia"), host of the [2024 UEFA Europa Conference League final](/wiki/2024_UEFA_Europa_Conference_League_final "2024 UEFA Europa Conference League final").{#cite_ref-134}

The [EuroLeague](/wiki/EuroLeague "EuroLeague") final has been hosted twice in 1985 and in [1993](/wiki/FIBA_European_Championship_1992%E2%80%9393 "FIBA European Championship 1992–93") at the [Peace and Friendship Stadium](/wiki/Peace_and_Friendship_Stadium "Peace and Friendship Stadium"), most known as SEF, a large indoor arena,^[\[134\]](#cite_note-135)^ and the third time in [2007](/wiki/2006%E2%80%9307_Euroleague "2006–07 Euroleague") at the [Olympic Indoor Hall](/wiki/Olympic_Indoor_Hall "Olympic Indoor Hall"). Events in other sports such as [athletics](/wiki/Track_and_field_athletics "Track and field athletics"), volleyball, [water polo](/wiki/Water_polo "Water polo") etc., have been hosted in the capital's venues.{#cite_ref-135}

Greater Athens is home to three widely supported and successful multi-sport clubs, [Panathinaikos](/wiki/Panathinaikos_A.O. "Panathinaikos A.O."), originated in the city of Athens, [Olympiacos](/wiki/Olympiacos_CFP "Olympiacos CFP"), originated in the port city of [Piraeus](/wiki/Piraeus "Piraeus") and [AEK](/wiki/A.E.K._(sports_club) "A.E.K. (sports club)"), originated in the suburban town of [Nea Filadelfeia](/wiki/Nea_Filadelfeia "Nea Filadelfeia"). In [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football"), [Olympiacos](/wiki/Olympiacos_F.C. "Olympiacos F.C.") is the dominant force at the national level and the only Greek club to have won a European competition, the [2023--24 UEFA Europa Conference League](/wiki/2023%E2%80%9324_UEFA_Europa_Conference_League "2023–24 UEFA Europa Conference League"), [Panathinaikos](/wiki/Panathinaikos_F.C. "Panathinaikos F.C.") made it to the [1971 European Cup Final](/wiki/1971_European_Cup_Final "1971 European Cup Final"), while [AEK Athens](/wiki/AEK_Athens_F.C. "AEK Athens F.C.") is the other member of the [big three](/wiki/P.O.K. "P.O.K."). These clubs also have successful [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball") teams; [Panathinaikos](/wiki/Panathinaikos_B.C. "Panathinaikos B.C.") and [Olympiacos](/wiki/Olympiacos_B.C. "Olympiacos B.C.") are considered among the top powers in Europe, having won the [EuroLeague](/wiki/EuroLeague "EuroLeague") seven and three times respectively, whilst [AEK Athens](/wiki/AEK_Athens_B.C. "AEK Athens B.C.") was the first Greek team to win a European trophy in any team sport.

Other notable clubs within the region are [Athinaikos](/wiki/Athinaikos "Athinaikos"), [Panionios](/wiki/Panionios "Panionios"), [Atromitos](/wiki/Atromitos_F.C. "Atromitos F.C."), [Apollon](/wiki/Apollon_Smyrni_F.C. "Apollon Smyrni F.C."), [Panellinios](/wiki/Panellinios_G.S. "Panellinios G.S."), [Egaleo F.C.](/wiki/Egaleo_F.C. "Egaleo F.C."), [Ethnikos Piraeus](/wiki/Ethnikos_Piraeus "Ethnikos Piraeus"), [Maroussi BC](/wiki/Maroussi_B.C. "Maroussi B.C.") and [Peristeri B.C.](/wiki/Peristeri_B.C. "Peristeri B.C.") Athenian clubs have also had domestic and international success in other sports.

The Athens area encompasses a variety of [terrain](/wiki/Terrain "Terrain"), notably hills and mountains rising around the city, and the capital is the only major city in Europe to be bisected by a [mountain range](/wiki/Mountain_range "Mountain range"). Four mountain ranges extend into city boundaries and thousands of kilometres of trails criss-cross the city and neighbouring areas, providing exercise and wilderness access on [foot](/wiki/Hiking "Hiking") and [bike](/wiki/Mountain_biking "Mountain biking").

Beyond Athens and across the prefecture of Attica, outdoor activities include [skiing](/wiki/Skiing "Skiing"), [rock climbing](/wiki/Rock_climbing "Rock climbing"), [hang gliding](/wiki/Hang_gliding "Hang gliding") and windsurfing. Numerous outdoor clubs serve these sports, including the Athens Chapter of the [Sierra Club](/wiki/Sierra_Club "Sierra Club"), which leads over 4,000 outings annually in the area.

Athens was awarded the 2004 Summer Olympics on 5 September 1997 in [Lausanne](/wiki/Lausanne "Lausanne"), Switzerland, after having lost a previous bid to host the [1996 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1996_Summer_Olympics "1996 Summer Olympics"), to [Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta"), United States.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-oly-23)^ It was to be the second time Athens would host the games, following the inaugural event of 1896. After an unsuccessful bid in 1990, the 1997 bid was radically improved, including an appeal to Greece's Olympic history. In the last round of voting, Athens defeated Rome with 66 votes to 41.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-oly-23)^ Prior to this round, the cities of [Buenos Aires](/wiki/Buenos_Aires "Buenos Aires"), Stockholm and [Cape Town](/wiki/Cape_Town "Cape Town") had been eliminated from competition, having received fewer votes.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-oly-23)^ Although the heavy cost was criticized, estimated at $1.5 billion, Athens was transformed into a more functional city that enjoys modern technology both in transportation and in modern [urban development](/wiki/Urban_planning "Urban planning").^[\[135\]](#cite_note-olyy-136)^ The games welcomed over 10,000 athletes from all 202 countries.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-olyy-136)^{#cite_ref-olyy_136-1}
